description: We stay for 3 nights, for fixing our frame after very bad road. We tirn electricity, nea church are water pipe.

name: Casa Gaia
description: This hotel has nice rooms to rent and large, secure parking for overlanders. Camping in big rigs is permitted, though the bathrooms close at 9:00 when the restaurant closes. Cobán is a natural stopping point between Lake Atitlan and Tikal. The road from Atitlan is long and slow. Casa Gaia was a welcomed stop for us. We stayed in a room ($45 USD) for the night in the rainy season. Food is reasonably priced and available all day.

name: Hostal Paraiso San Jose
description:
It’s really a paradise! Nice garden with ponds, surrounded by trees and palms.
It’s still under construction, but the finished parts are already so nice, modern and clean! They serve beer and breakfast, meals will come when it’s finished.
Lot’s of safe parking space, maybe they let you camp in your car, as camping in a tent is also possible. 
Dorms are 100q and rooms with bathrooms about 160q. 
If you are coming from the north, take the second gravel road on the left, 300m after the petrol station (the road is not on maps.me, but on Google Maps).

name: Field Mechanic Jose Maria ajú navichoc
description:
Owner of the Cafe Chuasinayi gave us this mechanics number. Helped us find a used rear differential same day and delivered in the evening from Quetzaltenango. Finished install following day. Work took place across the street from the cafe where the space can accomidate a bigger size vehicle. Jose was very helpful and didn't mind me helping out with the work. Even did a brake bleed for us. Very reasonable price for the work done and finished in a timely fashion. Number for mechanic: 33742366 whatsapp
Goes by Chema.
If number does not work ask for Chema the mechanic at the cafe. He does not have a shop so he will come to you.

name: Hotel Iquitiu
description: Secure parking lot. Dog friendly. Small kitchen on site not sure on hours open. Very clean room. Rotating fan on ceiling. Friendly owner & staff. Big rigs would have issues getting in through gate. Great view on top terrace. Coffee and pan provided in morning. Paid 235 for 1 night.

name: Agua Pura La Sirenita
description: Tel. 32004024 Very kind and helpul people! Monday to Saturday from 6AM to 07PM

name: Restaurant (free wifi) and gift shops
description:
Restaurant is cheaper than the Jaguar Inn (beer is the same, 22q).
But there’s free wifi and it‘s pretty fast!
The wifi at Jaguar Inn does barely work...

name: Coaba Farms Store
description:
This place is already in iOverlander as a restaurant but it’s so much more and definitely worth noting. 

They have a small store with all things organic (vegetables, amazing eggs, organic dairy, organic meats-bison, lamb, chicken etc.). They also have body care products! 

They also have a special Saturday market where they offer more vegetables! 

Open 8-4
Closed Monday

P.S.  they have yoga too, so many amazing things here!

name: Antigua Brewing Company
description: Great place with all different kind of craft beers, great food (the pulled pork burger is something else) nice rooftop terrace. Had a great time here.

name: Pets Paradise
description: We found some decent brands of dog food here. Purina and Acana and raw food, very expensive but they have it. They also have pet services for grooming it looks like.

name: Balneario Manantial
description: 20Q pp night, very friendly, clean Toilette and cold Pool and shower. Big rigs are welcome as well as dogs.

name: trail to indian nose (guided start)
description:
this is where u are driven by the shuttle if u book a guided hike to the indian nose. from here it is a mere 30 min hike along corn and coffee plantations.
we took a guide for Q90 pp for the sunrise hike. it is busy with guided groups, but i think for the early morning hike a guide is not a bad thing. by daylight the hike is easy to find of ur own (of course at own risk).

name: Casa Quixote
description:
Casa Quixote in Antigua Guatemala is a home away from home to many travelers. The house has 6 rooms of which three are available to rent all rooms have their private bathroom with hot water. We have a big enough parking lot for 2 RVs at a time also where we can provide cable electricity and water replenishing. The property is located just outside Antigua before entering the city, vast green and common areas in the garden with two toilets for the parking grounds, without having to enter the main house. Also we have a cabin bar to enjoy the company of other travelers share stories and relax. Breakfast can be provided, there is security and the area is calm and safe. Welcome to Casa Quixote

For more pictures look us up on FB or IG as casa_quixote.

name: Casa Santa Clara
description: Nice homestay / hostel in Antigua. Big secure parking, our two big motorbikes even sheltered. Nice and quiet to stay and to rest. Big and really good equipped kitchen, big living room with many couches, big terrace and nice backyard. A little, but expensive grocery in walking distance. Bigger supermarkets, a nice traditional market and the city centre are 5-10 minutes by public bus (1,50Quetzal pp one way). Paid 125Quetzal for a private double bedroom with own bathroom. We have found this place on AirBnB. You have to book via AirBnB, because the owner is just once or twice a day present. The owner Walter is really nice and helpful. Highly recommended.

name: Le kape
description: Hidden away next to the field you can camp on outside the carazon del bosque there is a super chilled cafe. The vibes are layed back and the coffee is top notch! Alberto owns the  of the field were you can camp and his sons run the cafe! Enjoy

name: San Lucas - Playa & boat ramp
description:
This is public parking at the lake front of San Lucas. You pay Q10 per day of parking (u get a receipt). they told us, someone was around all day and night, but didn't see security at night. it felt safe though. some people hanging out till later at night and locals in the morning, but usually that's a good thing in terms of safety.
there are public toilets for Q2 (flush/ no seat) and showers. nice views and moderately flat parking spaces.

name: ATM
description: closest ATM for Paredon on this side of the river. Super 24 store

name: bad road
description: if u are headed to Acatenango trailhead, it is better to take the CHM11 road from Antigua. even if you are coming from the coast, worth considering doing the detour via Antigua. the CHM 11 is a nicely paved road, whilst this one is a dirt road with many pot holes and washboard surface. totally doable, but nowhere nearly as comfortable.

name: Hotel Casa Jose
description:
Hotel Casa Jose is located at the end of a quiet residential street in Coban. Eliana is the owner and her house is next to the hotel (formerly house converted to provide 4-5 rooms of varying sizes all with private bathroom). 
Found this after a long day of driving using booking.com. Was able to negotiate a rate for two adults and one child (12 years old) - paid 250 quetzales for the night. She very kindly accommodated our request for dinner (25q pp) and also provides breakfast on site for an extra fee. Place is super nice and clean, beds are comfortable, great water pressure and you don't have to wait for hot water. Rooms are themed and we stayed in Las Conchas. Free WiFi which was decent. They offer secure gated parking for one or two cars - our Defender was able to fit. Otherwise parking on the street in front of the hotel. A welcome find after a long day of driving.

name: Aduana Express Aéreo Prorroga vehículos
description: The procedure is simple: 1) process the Extension of the Tourist visa at the GENERAL DIRECTORATE OF IMMIGRATION (6th Ave. #311 zone 4 Guatemala City tel. 2411-2411) They give you a term equal to the original one. They pay 25 dollars 2) with the stamp of the extension in the passport go to the CUSTOMS OFFICE that is in the Airport and is called EXPRESS AEREO. 3) Present the passport, the Document of the car and the permit for Import and Re-export of the car that they gave you at the border when entering. Nothing is paid. The authorization is at the moment. They gave us another 90 days. 4) Continue enjoying Guatemala

name: Don Lalo la kombi
description:
Excellent place to eat burgers and breads, they also have a vegetarian option, all very cheap from 10Q 100% recommended. Hours of operation from 6:00 p.m. to 10:00 p.m.
---
Excelente lugar para comer hamburguesas y panes, también cuentan con opción vegetariana todo muy barato desde 10Q 100% recomendado. Horario de atención desde las 18:00 hasta las 22:00

name: Volcano views
description: Flat near water. Small beach nearby. Fire pit and wood.

name: Narrow road barriers
description: The city has placed two yellow concrete barriers to prevent trucks passing, but we barely made it through in our g35 (literally less than an inch either side). Anything larger would be stuck and I'd hate to have to reverse back to the intersection with the amount of traffic it gets.

name: Restaurante Ital Espresso
description:
Great little restaurant/cafe with nice atmosphere, friendly staff, comfortable patio seating with a partial view of the lake, and good WiFi. Prices are not cheap but are normal for the area (20-35 for breakfast; 40-50 for most lunch/dinner plates). Not a bad place to rest and read or use internet and have a bite to eat, and enjoy the relaxed atmosphere. 

Also, the husband of the young woman who works here, named Walter, is a local conservationist and guide who does tours to El Mirador. I didn’t take the tour but he is a friend of a friend, buena onda, and seems like he would be a good guide.

name: Market Express
description:
Closest gas to the Guatemala border. 
Spend your extra q’s here.

name: Banco Industrial
description: One of the few (only?) places in the city centre that will change US dollars in denominations lower than $50 with only a passport. The exchange rate is decent and definitely better than that offered by unofficial exchanges. They won’t accept notes in poor condition or written on. They didn’t seem to accept currencies other than USD. Open until 6pm.

name: El Sazón de la Abuela
description: Pleasant restaurant with great food and friendly owners, at reasonable prices - this was our first meal in Guatemala and if they're all like this we'll be very happy! Paid 50 quetzales for two big breakfasts and drinks

name: Zeta Gas Auto Cuchilla
description:
Fill gas of RV integrated tanks ACME
24 hours open
Quickly service
Highly recommended.

name: Los Cenotes de Candelaria
description:
Getting here: follow google maps until you turn on to the dirt/unpaved road, then follow the white & red signs that say cenotes Candelaria. Google will take you the wrong way if you follow directions after the dirt road. You’ll go through a couple small towns but you won’t miss the signs. 

You’ll come to the entrance controlled by the locals and pay her 50q pp. Tell her you’re camping and she’ll ask how many tents. Since we’re sleeping in the truck she didn’t charge us anything extra. The road up to the cenotes are rocky so a bit of clearance or cautious driving would be best. It was dry when we came but it looks like it could get messy during wet season. 

Camping/parking at the 2nd cenote only. There’s a tienda, bathrooms and some shacks near the initial camping parqueo but if you keep following the road there are parking spots right next to the cenote 2. Absolute beautiful view of the cenote. The campground definitely needs some love but it’s expected with Covid and all. 

Arrived and a couple cars full of Guatemalans were swimming but after sundown we had the place to ourselves. 
We didn’t use the bathrooms or the tienda so I’m not sure what’s up with those but bring your own drinking water & food and enjoy this spectacular place!

name: Restaurante tortas Mila
description: The lady who owns/manages this restaurant/property is very generous to travellers. Behind the restaurant is a big parking space to stay overnight. Even further behind is where there is a water park that is currently closed but located in the park is where showers and toilet facilities are located for use. Would ask permission first if camping is available. This is the second time we stopped here in two months apart from stays. Dogs are fine. Restaurant with free WiFi inside. A drink or food purchase would be courteous. There is also a panderia (bakery) attached to the restaurant. Very tasty treats!

name: Monseñor Gregorio Schaffer Hospital
description: This is a hospital with clean drinking water available - there's a tank with taps where the villagers collect water just to the left when you enter the car park. we were led up to separate solar-powered tank on the roof. No charge for water.

name: Mama Brenda Piscinas Termales
description:
Just down the road there is a Turicentro with natural thermal pools.
Bealtiful place, with trees, especially to stay on the evening and night. Open until 22hs.
They only charged us the entrance (10 qtz pp) and allowed us to spend the night for free in their large parking lot. Very safe, Very nice and very cheap. Highly recommended.

name: Hotel Villa de Arcos
description: Very adequate hotel with secure parking for small to medium sized rigs. Probably nothing over about 3 meters (power lines hang low). Got a room with AC for 175q. Also, just a block from good, cheap street food. Wifi is best closer to reception. Showers are said to be warm, but they are those electric ones and when I turned the switch on the shower head to warm, the water zapped me. Not bad, but I’m not a fan of electricity while in the shower, so just left it cold. ;)

name: Cheap delicious street food
description: Several stalls selling plates of various meats with rice, beans, pasta salad, and tortillas. 15q/plate. I recommend the longaniza. A couple taco stands across the street and tiendas selling big cans of Gallo beer for 10q as well. Great place for a cheap, filling, and yummy feed, plus nice service.

name: Police check
description: Checked our passports, drivers licenses, documents, noted info down on their clipboard. Quick and friendly.

name: Dreamcatcher Eco Lodge
description: Very nice place for a break. The owner speaks English and is helpful. They have a dorm, simple private rooms and private cabin. We payed 200q per night for a private room. Excellent kitchen. More expensive then average, but almost ‘Haute cuisine’. You can park save at the Marina and the hotel boot will pick you up. If you are lucky you can see the monkeys in the trees above you and the turtles underneath you at the same time! From the hotel trips are arranged to Livingston.

name: Comida typica
description:
We stopped there until waiting (1 hour) our defensia on the truck was installed few meters away.

It’s a small comida tipica (which opened the day before we came !! )
Super clean toilets.
Good food and really good prices.
10 Q for the order of 3 tacos (really good)

Enough place to park next or in front of it.

Total : 26Q (3€) para 2 ordens de tacos + 4 limonadas. (see photos)
Definitely worth it !

Come and stop here to eat !

name: Polarizado el chino
description:
Right after the gas station and banrural bank.

Seller of “defensia”, small and bigs.
The best prices we found since we were linking for one in Mexico. 
Chetumal prices are crazy (16500 pesos for one big) here we paid (1500 quetzals) for the same thing, including installation.

Good job.
Done in 1 hour.
Also accept dollars.

To compare, in chetumal for a small “defensia” they asked us 5500 pesos. The same here was 1300 quetzals.

name: Texaco
description: We spend the night at Texaco, super quiet, illuminated. There is a Domino’s and a super 24.

name: Football field en route to Acatenango
description:
Big open field with a football pitch and fabulous views! The valley side has what looks like a water treatment plant in the making and a bit of rubbish - but views of the summit of Acatenango and Volcan del Fuego - had some amazing displays of lava at night! The other side is more sheltered - visible from the road but only just if you park up close to the road side where the ground rises up. 

I imagine it might get busier at weekends, but we had a nice peaceful night here.

name: El Punto - Very good restaurant
description: This is the best local cuisine I have had in Guatemala. We had the Menu del dia, beautifully cooked pork meatballs (kind of) with potatoes, avocado and blue corn tortas. We also had a soup starter... high end restaurant standard food and alll for just 25Q. The service was polite and friendly too. Somehow they call themselves a pizzeria restaurant. They do have wood fired pizzas, they are probably amazing too. But the menu offers more than just that and the standard of food is really very good. Highly recommended and amazing value.

name: Java Tech
description:
The VW Guatemala club recommended Javier, the owner of the workshop! Incredible but as soon as we arrived they began to help us to stop the brakes of our kombi and the homozygous 0km !! Super recommended! Wpp Javier: +50246223245

El club VW Guatemala nos recomendó a Javier, el dueño del taller! Increíble pero ni bien llegamos se pusieron a ayudarnos a dejar los frenos de nuestra kombi y la homocinetica 0km!! 
Súper recomendado! 
Wpp Javier: +50246223245

name: Right by the lake
description: Stayed one night on the side of the street by the lake. Safe and quiet. Asked the owner of a restaurant if we could park, he said no problem.

name: Los Amigos Hostel
description:
Best hostel ever. Great vibe, great people, location is in the middle of Flores so very convenient. 
The food is great and at a reasonable price. Pet friendly and a lot of fun. There's a night lounge after 9:30 pm and we also enjoyed that.
 Totally recommend.

name: Shipping with Seaboard (Corporación Menorha)
description:
We shipped our van in a 20’ container from Guatemala to Cartagena. We have a RDH van (Delica), so this seemed like the best option for us on our way south. This point is the office. 3rd story, gray building above a little pollo restaurant. The contact we went through was Mayden de Ralda. Her WhatsApp number is +502 5698 0994 (normally very quick to respond) and email is maydenderalda@corporacionmenorha.com. Although we got in touch a month in advance, she didn’t need confirmation of what ship we wanted until a week prior to sailing. The correspondence was easy- we sent via WhatsApp a copy of the vehicle title, the TIP, and passports. She sent the schedule for the following 4 weeks, a shipping quote for Seaboard, and the agency quote for themselves. The shipping cost $1003, and agency/port fees $525, so $1528 USD total on the Guatemala side. Our ship was to sail on a Wednesday, so Monday morning we arrived to begin the process, which went as follows.
1. Had everything we wanted to travel with packed up. Once the vehicle is in the port they don’t let you get anything out of it. 
2. Arrived at their office (opens at 8:30) wearing long pants and close toed shoes (hiking shoes worked, but with smaller thin shoes they won’t let you in). Met Mayden and she sent us with Ricardo to take the van to the port, just a block away. We left our bags in the office. 
3. Took with us our passports, TIP, TIP sticker, and copy of drivers license (can leave it all in the van, it stays with you for a while).
4. Ricardo gave us safety gear to wear and we began the rounds of stopping at several places to do lots of paperwork. He took care of all of it, only needing a few signatures. Because there were 2 of us, only the title holder can drive into the port, so the other person will ride on the back of Ricardo’s moto. There are a few stops to make (entrance, shipping booths, weighbridge, customs...)
5. After all the paperwork and shuffling around was taken care of, we left the car in the “bodega” for the night. Ricardo gave us rides back one by one to the entrance where we turned our badges in, got our passports back, and walked 1 block back to the office.
6. Back at the office, we made our payment to Mayden in cash (4069q). There was some confusion as to how to pay Seaboard, because you don’t do that through Mayden, nor the Seaboard office there. However, you have the option of paying that fee at the destination, which is apparently what most people do, and we will too (in Cartagena). The other option is to have with you the thousand dollars cash or thousand dollars worth of Quetzales in cash to deposit into the seaboard bank account. (I’ll report back how the payment goes on the Colombia side.)
7. I’ll just note, all of this took most of the day. We had a couple minor hiccups, so, efficiently, it could probably be done in a morning.
8. Done for the day, all that was left was to wait to hear from Mayden about what time slot we would get to put the van in the container for the following day. We stayed at a hotel just 5 min walk from the office.
9. We got the 8am slot, so we showed up at about 7:40 to the office and again went to the port with Ricardo to put the van into the awaiting container. The port workers drove it in, strapped it down, and locked it up. Took photos of the container number and seal number. This took less than an hour.
10. Back at the office, we got the final paperwork to take to Colombia, caught a taxi to the Litegua bus station in Puerto Barrios, and got a bus back to the city to catch our flight.

Overall, there’s nothing to stress about. The only thing I wish I would have known before was that the process takes 2 days. We ALMOST bought flights for Tuesday, but figured we wait a day “in case anything comes up with the shipping.” Good call. Also, Mayden is super nice, she even bought us a big bag of fruit for our bus ride, and Ricardo was an absolute legend flying around the port taking care of everything. Highly recommend shipping with them.

name: Car park next to Shell garage
description: Appears to be an overnight truck stop - quiet at night from 10ish but sporadically noisy in early morning when the trucks depart. Definitely less pleasant and peaceful than Posada Montaña del Quetzal up the road, but free, safe (patrolled by an armed guard at night) and toilets available in the garage shop - possibly also outside; didn't investigate. An external tap too.

name: Pet hotel and grooming
description: Left our two dogs here for two nights while we visited Semuc Champey. Great service. Paid 100 quetzales for each dog per night. There are smaller kennels available for 75 quetzales. Our small dog got a hair cut and that was also 100 quetzales. Our big dog got her nails filed for free. Both smelled really good when we picked them up! They also sent us pictures daily. Totally recommend! Plus, dogs aren't allowed in Semuc.

name: Agua Pura Santa Marta
description: Filtered Water Q.8 for a 5 gallons, looks clean and sanitary.

name: Shell gas station to spend the night
description: Arrived around 6 pm asked if it was ok to park and sleep in our van, they said ok and that it was safe. Opened 24 hrs, a few other trucks stayed the night as well. Also, there is wifi inside the shell.

name: Dr Max Catalan
description: A very good doctor if any medical assistance is needed.

name: Taller de Herrerio
description: Awesome welding/fabrication shop! My roof rack was weekended by weeks on the beach and the roads in Guatemala were too much. Oscar fabricated new braces to hold the rack in a matter of hours. I searched around town for a welder and this is definitely the best I could find.

name: Puma Gás Station
description: No wi-fi, but good flat place to stop, 24h, lots of truckers stoped at night, felt safe, has showers and toilets but in a really bad condition...

name: Gas Station
description: Slept the night here, safe & quiet. This gas station is not opened 24 hrs, closes at 11. A few trucks parked around, we stayed with another overlander. No problems.

name: Cunen Bomberos
description: Took refuge from the rain at this sweet little fire station. Outfitted with a bed, a beeeeyutiful balcony, and an adorable guy who reminds me of my grandpa. We parked our bicycles in the lower level.

name: Bomberos Aguacatan/Public Parking Lot
description: Small local firestation, big dirt parking lot. Tons of stray dogs roaming about. Ask firestation if you can take a shower or use the bathroom, we did. Lots of trucks, tuk Tuks Park here at night. Tent/RV camping is chill.

name: La Combi
description:
Great place to stop and listen to the stories of Javier and his wife who are both amazing hosts trying to make your stay as enjoyable as possible.

Campground and park , with motocross tracks and children playground. Backpackers, RVs, bikers, welcome! We have fresh water showers, toilets, place to park big enough for big rigs and food service available. Close to border with El Salvador and warm weather all year. Right outside of Chiquimuñilla Km 117

name: Pan Superior
description: Awesome bakery on the street where there are lots of street vendors.

name: El Telefono
description:
There is few (two) hostels in this street. Very good vibes, family style hotel/hostel, no dorms but cheap rooms of one or two beds:  <50q pp.
Amazing view from the (green and orange) terrace on the traditional type cemetery, and close to the legendary market. 
Quiet vibes, good for relaxing, friendly owners.

name: Very nice food stand
description: Wonderful and cheap fresh food. Shaded place to sit. Very friendly people. Let us try to make our own tortillas.

name: Don Arturo Gas Station
description: New gas station, great to spend the night on the way... noisy though.

name: Mazatenango Hostal Casa Real
description: Familiar hotel in town . Nice for one night. The family is very friendly. 80 pesos / person

name: Hôtel Texas
description:
Hotel in town , with wifi, swimming pool.
We paid 220 quetzales for a room with air conditioning and 2 beds

name: La fonda de Minchez
description:
BEST FOOD!!! Everyone must stop here! The people are so lovely and the food is made with all the love. Veggie and Vegan friendly. None expensive. There salsa will will change your life. 

Strategically well located restaurant before or after crossing the Guatemala-Mexiko border. Reasonably priced breakfast with a satisfying taste. Good.

name: Punto Cero
description: I waited in this place for a long time, 10 mins, there were people playing cards at the bar and no one attended to me.

name: Marea Roja - restaurante
description:
The owner Hugo Oliva is an incredibly friendly man. I have no idea why, but he offered both my husband and myself free drinks and dessert. We will also stay overnight (free) in the parking lot. It's a seafood and meat restaurant that is a bit more expensive but they are delicious and very big meals. Lunch and Supper only. Closes at 7pm.  
ALSO - Thursday, Fri, Sat and Sun nights they sell Mexican-style tacos at 3 for $25Q. Again, a lot of meat and you choose your own toppings! 7pm-1am

name: bathrooms and showers free)
description:
I believe the showers are free, and they're relatively clean! At a very large Texaco gas station complex. The shower building is at the back with. Large DUCHAS sign on it!

There's also a covered seating area to enjoy a snack in the shade. We made breakfast here no problem. Very friendly staff.

name: Hostel
description: The hostal ‘a place to stay’ is owned by Raul and his family. They are the nicest people I’ve met. They a a lot of cats and a rabbit which makes it feel like at home. They are happy to arrange everything (transport, excursions,...) for you for good prices and work only with people they trust. You can use the shared kitchen and they have laundry facilities. A dining and seating area outside, which is cosy. Definitely would stay here again!! Short walk to the city centre! Breakfast included.

name: Happy Fish
description:
Great breakfasts and a crazy good frappucino-choco-banana (espresso-chocolate-banana-ice).

Fast and very attentive staff.

name: Playa Salvador Gaviota
description:
Little bar right at the beach. Great offer of cool beers and coconut (10Q/coconut) and restaurant.
The beach is not that clean but the view is really cool and we had the place almost for us alone.

To reach the beach, you need to take a Tuk-tuk in Livingstone and ask for the “Salvador Gaviota” beach. We paid 5Q pp 1 way and then walk through the wooden bridge and along the beach till you reach the bar.

name: La Sombrero Ecotourism
description:
A great pet option! Okay so it's actually a hotel BUT they allow campers (tent or camper-style) for $80Q per couple. Not sure if the price is the same for a single. We wanted to check our the ruins but dogs are not permitted, therefore we couldn't camp with a dog either. They offered to watch our dog so we could go to the ruins together. It was a 15 minute bumpy (but decent road) drive to the ruins from here including ticket purchase.

We had access to bathrooms and showers (only cold), and all the common areas. The camping space is really their front lawn by the water and it was super peaceful, with the added ambiance of howling monkeys. Restaurant on site. They had no issues with us cooking our own food. There's a public wooden sink by the pier we used to wash our dishes while no one was around.

If you plan to rent a room, book in advance.

Big rigs unknown.... It's a tight fit but long tour vans can fit.

name: Las Gardenias Hotel
description:
Nice hotel in El Remate, very well located for a day-trip to Tikal and Flores.
Prices depend on the room’s equipement: 150Q/night for a king size bed + fan (no A/C) + TV + private bathroom. I think it was 200Q/night with A/C. 
Spotless clean but beware of the ants if you let some food in your room. 
Each room has a little terrace with table and/or hammock facing the full-of-birds-and-plants patio.
Fast WiFi available everywhere.

The game changer for us: the hotel has a little gated parking for 4 cars just in front of the entrance. We could park our van (2,50m high) there. The gate is closed at night and it feels really safe.

Restaurant on site - count 40Q to 50Q for a main, 30 to 40Q for breakfast. They have really good smoothies too.

Tip: a “señor” comes every day to the restaurant to sell its banana bread and carrot cake. He is there in the morning and often back again around midday. The banana bread is an absolute delight. One whole bread is 30Q. Half a carrot cake is 20Q.

The hotel also organized our trip to Tikal. 125Qpp round trip to the site, with a guide onsite. You still have to add the 150Q pp for the reserve entrance. Outbound at 5.30pm, so you are quite alone onsite when you starts the tour.

name: Hotel Chicago
description:
Basic Hotel. 
locked/secure parking in central area - see photos. 
150q for room with double bed. 
WiFi - yes. A/C - no. 
------- 
WhatsApp (+502)930-2615 and (+502)5575-7086
(didn't respond to us however)
-------
lovely vibe in the town though, feels safe and view of the volcanoes.

name: IxomOn hostel
description:
This hostel is running by a lovely couple with three dogs and two cats. If you're pets lover this is your place. They have a big yard with space for two small van and an open space por one or two big rigs. I took one room with breakfast included, but I think you can manage with them just for camping. It's a little bit far from center (6_8) min by car but it worth the views and peace around. 
I loved the hostel because my dog had a lot of place for running and playing with the other dogs. 
Contact Charlie: +502 5991 6813

name: Taller Libelula (amazing mechanic)
description: This is an amazing workshop. it's located in a quite area and the mechanics are super nice. There is a lot of know-how and tools available.  they were able to open and fix my BMW gearbox of the Land Rover, which is one of the most difficult jobs ever.

name: Tienda main road
description: Small parking lot behind the tienda on the main road. There’s a dirt road right before the tienda where you can park and it belongs to the owner of the tienda. We stayed for one night, the owner is very friendly and asked for 20 quetzales for the night.

name: Hotel Santa Monica
description: Nice, clean, hotel with a pool, wifi, and AC. Cost me $170 QZ. Located right on CA9 in Los Amates. One of the nicer stays I have had in CA. *Wi-Fi only near lounge area

name: Gas station San Carlos.
description: Very old but huge gas station open 24hrs close to the road. We asked the guard if we can stay overnight and he said yes right way. Very nice people. He didn’t ask but I gave him 20 Q and a soda.

name: ATM BANCO DE DESARROLLO RURAL
description: Bank with an ATM to be able to withdraw money.

name: Lavenderia del Rio
description: 20qtz el kilo - good service - we had our clothes the next morning

name: Hotel Terra Maya Showers
description:
Hot showers with great pressure for 15Q 
Considering the 10Q cold showers in Antigua, if you’re near this location. it’s worth it!

name: ASOAVA Acatenango community guides
description:
We rarely do tours, but this is a true Guatemala experience. Catalino picked us up from the tourist police park and took us to his house in San Jose where we slept and had a home made dinner with his family, cooked by his wife.
Before trekking the Acatenango volcano,  ASOAVA offered us direct contact with the guides without an agency intermediating (we felt our money was going to who really deserves it). It was just me, my girlfriend and our dog Pancho trekking, with a guide just for us, not the typical excursion. Once again we were offered home made meals while in the volcano, they offered us jackets, gloves, hats, sleeping bags and a tent with an amazing view to the volcano. The trekking took us 4 hours to reach the campground on the first day. We spent the night watching a beautiful show of lava explosions right in front of us, cooking dinner and drinking hot chocolate around a fire pit. On the 2nd day we woke up at 4am to start a 1h30 trek to the top of the volcano to watch the sunrise while the fire explosions continue! Catalino told us the best way to contact him is trough WhatsApp and Facebook, so we’ll leave his number here 
tel: +502 55004707 
Hope you enjoy it like we did :)

name: Shower
description: Servicio Don Arturo . Hot shower at the gas station, ask to the staff. Free

name: Tito’s Garage
description:
Great mechanic, very helpful and hardworking. Was able to park at the location with no problems for two days, he drove me back and forth an hour away, on two different days. My clutch cable snapped, They don’t have VW bus parts in this part of Guatemala, he was able to find a similar cable was able to find a place to adapt it. Extremely wonderful and hospitable people the family let me use the bathroom/shower and even made me breakfast and coffee in the morning.

All this cost me only 150Q

name: Energía Solar
description: Solar business selling parts, panels, charge controllers, inverters, batteries and more. They also provide consultations, diagnostics and installation. They are kind and patient, Spanish speaking only.

name: Tienda Lolita
description:
The friendly family here allow parking in their large lot for 30Q day. We used this whilst hiking the volcano, and also stayed a night, no problems. Relatively quiet at night, felt safe to leave our vehicle here.

Small shop and delicious tostadas! (3Q each)

name: Señora María Laundry
description:
We saw Señora Maria washing clothes and we asked her if she could do ours. She washes by hand so you have to give her a little bit of time. Perfect to drop off before going to Tikal and collecting the following morning.  It was really
Cheap considering everything we had to wash, including towels, a duvet and dogs bed!

name: Paseo del Lago
description:
A small park with lake views. The lovely policeman on duty, Freddy, watched our van for us while we were at the climbing area and let us stay the night there (he was guarding the entrance all night). We cooked him dinner and spent hours practicing our Spanglish together, super friendly! 

Note: this road doesn't go through to the north, despite what Google says! only passable on a motorbike.

name: Chichicastenango family garden
description: Nice spot on family garden. Very friendly family. Ask for Doña Ana o Don Tomás. They start the overland activity with us and that is the reason that in this moment only can park an fill water, but in the future they will improve the service. The place is about 10 minutes walking to the market area, is quiet at night, flat and secure.

name: Shell gas station
description: Gas station operates 24/7, small store closes at 7 pm. Loads of truck drivers staying overnight. Simple but clean bathrooms. Not sure if they have a shower. In the evening traffic calmed down. Friendly and helpful staff.

name: Turicentro Vista Hermosa
description: A nice place overlooking the valley far enough from the road to be very quiet. It’s a jardín de eventos with a couple of swimming pools, bathrooms and showers and a tienda and the very friendly owners prepare simple meals for a decent price. The access road is quite rough and steep and there is a height limit of about 2.30 m. For two people in a camper van we paid Q50 (after bargaining a little bit).

name: Parqueo Central
description: It’s a large car parking in front of the church in the town center of Todos Santos. The gate is closed from 6 pm. to 6 am. but it’s not fenced and there’s no night guard on duty. It’s very busy during the day but it calms down at sunset and from 10 p.m. the only noise is from barking dogs all around. Q10/vehicle.

name: Hotel y Restaurante Secretos del Lago
description: Nice place to camping, near a hotel and restaurant, you only pay Q.50, it’s a nice place to camping

name: Jorge y Ronald Mechanics
description:
Honest and excellent mechanics in Colomba. They’ve fixed our gas pump and our differential on our 28ft motorhome. We recommend them on a heart beat, awesome people.
Jorge 5727-6060
Ronald 5460-6774
If you don’t speak Spanish, call Shane at 4657-0812 . He is an awesome American that runs a mission to help the kids in the village getting educated, he will help you and he is a good friend of the mechanics.

name: Rincon Suizo
description:
Grassy spot 25m above the highway.
No dogs barking, no music.
Free
Truck noise did not bother when sleeping with windows closed (it was around 5°C at night)
Female toilets were still open at 22:00, not sure if they ever lock them.

Ask at Caja (restaurant check out) for permission to camp.

Go up on Parqueo 3 which is likely almost always empty except of a Chevrolet oldtimer and 3 cars of employees.

Water Faucets all arround this parking lot. Normal water hose does not connect to them, you need a 1/2 inch male thread.
Next to male toilet is a 'pila'. There is also a big washing machine, did not ask if we can use it.

Little cute hike through the forest.
Playground

We hung out in the restaurant without consuming to enjoy the fire chimneys.

Crepes and desserts of the restaurant are very tempting.

Safe as there are guards on duty and cameras all over.

Restaurant:
Capuchino 15Q
Breakfast 28-55Q
Plates: 26-67Q
Beer: 25Q
Crepes: 40-80Q (gluten free option)
Very professionaly run, Very popular to Guatemaltecia from the City

name: Mandarina Cafe
description: Mandarina Café is an awesome place co-owned by Australian and Guatemaltec ladies. They have awesome café, gluten free and vegan treats, their breakfast are to die for! This is the place to eat in Quetzaltenango when you are healthy!!!

name: Cruz Roja Purulhá
description:
Very kind people at Cruz Roja. 
Spent a night
I’m a cyclist but there is space for big cars also

name: Aceitera - Oil Change
description:
Isayas charged 50Q for oil change.
He seemend honest and discovered a gasoline leak.

4,73l Caatrol oil syntetic 350Q
Natural 250Q

name: Multiservicios Revolorio
description: I lost coolant, these guys found the leak and fixed it up. they were nice and helpful.

name: La Cabaña De Tío Conejo
description:
Incredible hospitality by the owner Tío Conejo. Was allowed to camp with no issues he even extended a electricity bar to my bus so I can charge my phone, also there’s access to a swimming pool and a small BBQ pit.

Great and helpful host, 5 minute walk from the beach.

name: Finca el Amate
description:
Nice place to camp with amazing views!! The price to camping crazy Q.125 per person. 

Un lugar increíble para acampar, con impresionantes vistas. Q.125 por persona para acampar.

name: Agua Pura de la Roca
description: Super nice guy. Fill up 20 litres for free.

name: Taller Mécanico Giovanni
description: Giovanni is a trained car mechanic. He worked on our car on a Sunday and did a thorough job. He found good solutions to problems despite of lack of spare parts.

name: DHL-Shop to send drones avoiding Nicaragua !!!
description:
Drone are forbidden by law in Nicaragua. When coming to the border they will take them forever!!!
The lady in DHL Antigua speaks English well.

With DHL Express and sending to Costa Rica or Panama you are fine and lucky.

name: Mr Jeff
description:
Lavanderia and dry cleaning. The place looks very new and modern.
70Q for one big bag of clothing.

name: Panorama Ranch
description:
Beautiful ranch with an incredible view of Acatenango Volcano, organic avocado orchard, mango trees, banana trees and coffee plants. It is Rolando’s ranch, he’s very friendly and warm. Spanish only. Plenty of space for cars and larger rigs, pretty flat and grassy land amidst the avocado trees. A few friendly dogs. He’s also building a fish pond in the beginning of January. Toilet and shower in the little farmhouse. Very quiet, secluded and secure with someone always onsite. In the morning you can clearly see the volcano, it’s very close!! And if you’re hiking the volcano, Rolando can get the bus for you. Rolando’s son Jason is a great cook and can make food for you. Good cell reception. 50 Quetzales per person, so worth it! 

Take little windy roads through the small town, down the dirt road past sugarcane and trees painted white. Big rigs may have a little trouble on the skinny roads!

name: Julio Mecanico
description:
Good young mechanic that made the extra mile to fix our camper van. Speaks only Spanish. 
Julio Tel: 3362-6657.

name: RN5 (going west)
description:
From here traveling to the west on the RN5 you have 27km very rocky road. First 10km reasonable gravel. Then narrow rocky road. High clearance absolutely necessary. It took us 2.5 hours with a small 4x4 truck. 2x we were stopped by a rope blocking the road. One guy was very rude, asking 100Q he picked up a stone but we where not impressed and drove through the rope. The second guy about 10 km further was very polite, he was actually repairing with a shovel the bad spots. We gave him 10Q and some cookies, he was very happy with this. Beautiful scenery, with a lot of local children waving and shouting "gringos!"

This road is in truly horrible condition and should be avoided. The roads going around are always the better option.

name: Laguna de Ayarza
description: We wanted to stay at the Restaurant Secretos del Lago. But I think, it is abandoned. So we drove a little further and found this beautiful place. The site is free, but you have to pay 30 quetzales at the entrance of the park. There is a palapa with a fogon and water faucet nearby.

name: Tropigas
description: Got 20 lbs for 88 quetzales filled Into my garafa. Friendly stuff.

name: Area below road
description:
This is a flat sandy area below the road. It is hidden from the road with some noise from traffic. Good view of Volcano de Aqua. 

More suitable for motorbike, walkers and cyclists. Not much space to turn around a vehicle. I encountered sandflies and mosquitoes here.

name: Ocós beach
description:
Gravel road going parallel to the beach, after the village not much is going on apart some abandonned houses, plantations and palapas. 
A local said it's ok to camp somewhere along here, so I picked a palapa that seemed accessible and free. take care if you drive in the sand (take some air off the tires). some nice waves to surf. quiet.

name: Balneario El Chulaquito
description: Large, nice and very well kept place with a pool filled with crystal clear water from a creek. There are lots of palapas, tables and benches, a couple of BBQs, a children’s playground and a small bar. Cold outdoor shower (no soap allowed). There is WiFi and electricity where you could plug in but we didn’t check that. Quiet at night (except the road noise) but very busy on a Sunday afternoon. Paid Q50 for two people in a camper right at the pool (see picture).

name: La Garza
description: Backpacks, sleeping bags, tents, knifes, flashlights, thermobottles, bottles, small camping gear

name: Resortes de León
description: Best place in Guatemala City and country for fixing truck suspension. They are very professional and can fix any trucks and cars. We had problem with our air bags and we canceled them by adding leaf springs on both side. The estimate was accurate and we didn’t paid one penny more than what they estimated it for. Can fit any big rig!!

name: Veterinaria Pets and More
description: The veterinarian is incredibly helpful with the health certificate and export permit needed to cross the border from Guatemala to El Salvador. Very knowledgeable with reasonable rates. Speaks good English as well. Highly recommend! (Tried to get the coordinates as accurate as possible, but it's easy to find in a search, by name, on Google maps.)

name: Taurino’s Steak House
description:
Restaurant building next to service station. 

Good quality food and sides, steaks dish Q75. 
Tasty menu de dia. Q35
Also both dishes came with a few sides, delicious soup and drink.

name: Maico Electromecanico
description:
We had an electrical problem with our transmission and Maico gave us a super service and fixed our problem very quickly!
Strongly recommend ;)
+502-4776-5446

name: La Trufa Chapina chocolateria
description: Delicious handmade chocolate.  Family business.  They also offer workshops.

name: Hotel El Ray Conquistador
description: Older three story hotel in the town of Malacatán. Clean, plenty of off street parking, bicycles can go in room.  No air-conditioning but good ceiling fan.  Cold shower.  90Q for single room.

name: Tikal ticket check
description:
Here is the boom gate where you enter the Tikal ruins by foot only. The tickets you bought 17km down the road at Tikal main entrance are checked here and you get a bracelet.

Enter by car here to get on the road which takes you in 23km to the town and ruins of Uaxactún. Tickets to Uaxactún cost 50Q pp and can be bought at Main entrance only. You additionaly need a permit to enter which you get at Tikal Main entrance or at the administration building a couple of 100m from here.

Road to Uacaxtún is a very decent dirt road with yearly maintenance. 4km before the town the maintenance crew was still fixing the last stretch but was still in good condition for 2WD and RVs.

After visiting Uaxactún you can visit Tikal ruins without having to pay 150Q extra by parking at the turn off to temple IV which is approx. 1km from the Tikal ticket check boom gate.

name: Nuevo Horizonte comunidad
description:
This is just  little piece of paradise.
if you want to enjoy the nature and discover the history last 40 years of Guatemala you have to come here. Just open your mind and try to think what happened here from the '60 to '96. 
we stayed three days in the center of the village with our big truck, here you have a small restaurant so e little shop and a really nice small bar where you can drink a beer. 
There is a laguna to discover, a bosque and all the story of this self sufficient community.
other option to overnight is in front of the laguna, really a gem.

name: Ciao Cacao
description: Whole vegan cafe place, serving hot and iced coffee, some vegan sweets and vegan ice-bars in various flavours. They have nice garden with hammocks and tables.

name: Dormidero Maya Hotel
description: A hotel 15 minutes walk from the island of Flores. Offers rooms with balcony, private bathroom and AC. We got ours with two beds (single and double) for 200 Q for the two of us. Bit out-dated but clean. We couldn't connect to the WiFi on our room, but seems signal is stronger downstairs. They have huge fenced parking lot. We found only one electricity plug in our room (was in the bathroom). Only cold water in the shower, at least in the room we got.

name: Parqueo
description: 5 q per hour to park here while checking iut the church

name: Taller Mambo Soldering
description: Our exhaust pipe fell and this shop was fast, professional, and cheap. They completely re-soldered our exhaust pipe for 60 Q and the owner said they can help with any soldering needs car or otherwise

name: Gasolinera Don Rolando
description:
Buen punto intermedio en el camino desde/hacia Semuc Champey - Flores en gasolinera Don Rolando. Parqueo, baños y ducha sucios pero todo gratis. Estándar Wi-Fi Rolando-2019. Ruidosa ya que está a la par de la carretera y funciona 24h.

Good mid rest point on the way from/to Semuc Champey-Flores at Gas Station Don Rolando. Parking, dirty bathroom and cold shower but all free. There's a basic Wi-Fi Rolando-2019. Do noisy ad it's next to the street and it's 24h open.

name: Hidden Wave Surf Hostel
description: Big sand parking lot at 2 minutes walking from the surf beach. 60Q/night/pers

name: Verde Eventos
description: This site is a park where they host weddings, birthday parties, etc... it s big, has a flat parking area, toilets, and there is a big truck entrance (not the main entrance). Isaac asked 75qtz/night/van *increased to 100qtz/night/van. (Now it is 125Q only for small cars. Anything that looks like a camper or bigger is 150Q or 200Q plus 25Q per person after 2).  One night there was a party, but finished around 10pm. We think it's a beautiful parking spot, compared to the other ones, with flowers, plants and all. Toilets were quite clean. A couple of water taps are around but not very many . Very calm at night. Isaac (the door guy) lives there, so even if it s closed, you can ring and he will be happy to host you. Easy and quick walk to center. Isaac s number +50231574343

name: Car Wash/Auto parts
description: Decent carwash for 25 q, well stocked parts store across the street. Nice place to hang out while they wash your car as well

name: La Luna Coffee&Chocolate
description: Unique and beautiful café, sip a hot chocolate or some coffee surrounded by beautiful things. they also have food, but we didn't try it. great place to spend a couple of hours even.

name: Parqueo
description: Parking, no height restriction, just saw it, didn't check the prices

name: Mercado de Antigua
description: Huge market where you find everything from fruits and vegetables, to electronic stuff and food. Funny to see and good prices!

name: Servicentro Formula Uno
description: Nice and professional mechanic! They did a very good jobs servicing our brakes!

name: Casa del Rey
description:
fancy hotel, a bit out of town, very quiet. 
huge grassy parking lot. 150Q/camper per night.
use of bathrooms in the reception area.

name: Automax
description:
Came to check the breaks. Very professional, didn’t need to do much work but knew his job! 
They even attended us after closing hours on Saturday (14h)

name: Cafe San Juan
description:
Don’t think you are being tricked by stopping in one of the first cafes coming down the lancha! Coffee here is of high standards, its made with an italian coffee machine and each coffee comes with the barista presentation.
They plant and process their own coffee, even if you’ve been to other fincas it’s a really nice stop in San Juan if you love coffee

name: Artesanos de San Juan
description:
Great cooperative of 35 women, who show you and teach for free how you pick the cotton, prepare it, dye it and creat the tejidos. All 100% natual processes. The ladies are very nice and it’s really interesting to learn about how the beautiful fabric is made.
There’s a a shop where they sell their products so if you want to buy something, better do it here because it goes straight to the women and cooperative : 80% for the families, 15% to the cooperative and 5% to maintain the infrastructure 
Highly recommended!

name: Utz Hua
description: Typical Guatemalan kitchen only at this restaurant! Very friendly service! Dishes between $30 and $50 quetzals.. we had a wonderful authentic chicken dish. We finished with a coffee and a cookie.. close to the parque

name: SENDERO Ecológico “el aprisco”
description: Beautiful grassy area surrounded by a pine forest focused on preservation of the forest. For day use by locals (or you), playground and trails into the forest, used for educational purposes as well. Crowded on a Sunday but everyone was gone by 1700. The owner, Nicholas was happy to have us in our Tacoma for one night, 35qz pp. Not for big rigs. Parking area only offered a few flat spots. The grassy area is flat for tent camping as well. Flush toilets and running water (nonpotable though!) No food or drinking water available on site. No WiFi, just spotty 3g. Gate is locked all day and Nicholas lives on the grounds. Felt extremely safe and welcomed. The morning after, a group of locals arrived for what seemed like a church service/gathering. Everyone was so nice. Pets are not allowed but he let us keep our husky in the car until everyone left. There’s one older female dog on the grounds but keeps to herself and is a good security system. Great stay for one night!

name: Gasolinera TechRon
description:
Gas Station with a small store with bathroom inside. A bit noisy because it's st the main street. Open until 10pm, then a security guard all night. Free, we couldn't find other place for free around.

ESPANOL
Gasolinera con una pequeña tienda con sanitarios. Algo ruidoso por estar sobre la carretera principal. Abierto hasta las 10pm y luego guarda de seguridad armado toda la noche. Gratis no encontramos ningún otro lugar gratis por la zona.

name: Tropigas
description: This place will fill your bottles by the weight. The Zgas on iOverlander only does by the full 20pounds (even if you have half empty bottle). Here we paid 88 quetzal for 20 pounds.. go in, they weigh your bottle, then you get paper at gate, then pay and then they fill up.. very friendly!!

name: Anita Mayan Cooking Class
description:
Incredible cooking class run by a local woman, Anita, who uses the class to empower other single mothers around the lake. You will get to choose between a few options for your main course, side, dessert, and drink. Once you've chosen, she'll take you to the local market, where she knows the vendors and take you around to buy the necessary ingredients. From there, you'll walk to her house (where this pin is placed) and start chopping! The cooking part lasts 3 hours including the meal. Her story is incredible and beautiful. She runs the class in English and Spanish. 275Q pp is well worth it, especially knowing the money goes back into supporting women in the community.

Anita is a trained tour guide who started her own company thanks to her tourism experience. She helps support single mothers by providing jobs, running a local weaving co-op, and fundraising for scholarships for children of single mothers to be able to attend elementary through high school.

To get in touch with Anita and book the class:

E-mail: mayankitchen88@gmail.com
Phone: +502 5824 7440

name: Hôtel Berthelot
description: Nice place for 150 quetzal , it's Clean and very quiet . There is a swimming pool but its dirty. It's possible to put the bicycle in à room.

name: Private Cabaña
description: Its a small cabin in the mountain with View of the lake. Its has one huge bed, a clóset, a desk to work. Also has a wonderfull bathroom with a big shower with views at the lake. The owners are a wonderfull family that lives in the house down in front of the lake. They also offer safe parking lot to all sizes motorhomes.

name: Local restaurant inside tikal
description: Great place for some local lunch in the park. You need to stop by in the morning before starting your tour as it's reservation only. 125Q pp with a fresh juice and worth it in my opinion.

name: Taller Chivas
description:
not the prettiest workshop but a friendly mechanic who changed the brake fluid

+50230196105 rodrigo

name: Carolina’s Resort
description: Stayed here before crossing the border back into Mexico. Really nice place with a bar, pool, and WiFi (though not really in the room). We paid 23$ for two people even though their initial price was 28$ for valentines weekend. Rooms were clean and we had two double beds. Shower was cold but still a nice bathroom. There are two other places next door as well but they were around the same price.

name: Miguel Angel Peche boat tours
description:
Miguel Angel is a great and humble guide who lives in the town just in front of Flores. He’s very interesting and offers different kinds of tours. He tries to clean the lake and preserve their land and culture. Highly recommended if you want to visit the lake by lancha. This spot is where he stays with his boat but you can contact him via Whatsapp +50253206540 
We took a 1h tour for 200Q, but he can offer a wide variety of tours and prices

name: River refreshing
description:
Blue water in the river, no people, one of THE overlander spots. 
see you on the road - your Diesel-Gypsies!

name: El Ganadero
description: Stoped for a late breakfast and had a wonderful brunch at this beautiful rural restaurant.

name: Llanresa - Chemaltenango - Serious mécanico / repair workshop
description: Serious, well organized and professional  team and workshop. Did a good job to change the bolts of the back dobble wheels of our RV Ford Transit. This « the » Guatemalan city for garage and repairs (all the bus and trucks of the country come in Chemaltenango) => Gives you access to many different solutions, material and spare parts nearby if needed. Llanressa is Easy to find, just at the back of Uno gaz station, which is on the main road. Highly recommend.

name: Parking with playground
description: Parking for several shops including depensa, burger king (wifi). In front of the parking lot is a small soccer field and a children's playground. Friendly security guard. Water tap.....other guy-could not find the tap..

name: Lake Atitlan Spanish School
description:
Excellent Spanish school in San Pedro. 
Teachers are really qualified and Selvin, the director goes beyond his school duties to help you out with any needs. 
The have single or couple classes, for 2,3 or 4 hours per day. 
Rates are available at their website

https://lakeatitlanspanishschool.com/pricing/

They do a test before starting the classes so to assess your Spanish level and tailor classes around your needs. 
They always offer activities in the afternoon, like cooking classes and weaving classes so to practice the language. 
It is also possible to stay by a host family, in order to get a full experience. 

We spent almost two weeks at the school and could really improve our Spanish. 

My teacher’s name was Marlon and I highly recommend him. I knew a bit of Spanish before starting the school and in 10 days he could really elevate my level.

name: Custom Boots Shops
description: This town just north of Antigua is famous for it's leather shops, mainly shoes and boots. there are dozens of shops hand making boots. it took me about 15 minutes to get my measurements, pick a material, style and color for custom made boots. was half the price of store bought shoes in the USA. worth ordering while you explore Antigua

name: Dismar - reflective tape & RV parts
description:
Here they sell the red&white reflective tape ("cintas reflectivas" mandatory for big rigs in Honduras)
7 quetzales for each red-white combo (1ft)
We put three on each side of the motorhome (rear, middle, front) and two on the back

name: AKI ferreteria - warning triangles for Honduras
description:
Commercial center "Parador del Rio" with food (La Torre), hardware (AKI) and clothing shops
At AKI they sell warning triangles and as we were heading to Honduras we needed two (it is mandatory and they should be 1ft tall)
About 60 quetzales each

If you are looking for reflective tape (also mandatory in Honduras but only for big rigs) the marine shop "Dismar" a little further on the right before crossing the bridge have some

name: Market and celebration
description: Local celebration and everyday market here

name: Keisha Coffee Shop
description:
This is a very relaxing atmosphere, a small coffee shop with WiFi, it has good music and great artisanal chocolate. (12qz) or 19qz with whipped cream. 
They are dog-friendly. And owners can give you many tips about where to go

name: Hotel Pino Montana - AKELA
description:
Coming from México on the right side before Huehuetenango.  Large secure parking for any size RV.  On Pan-Am Hwy. 
Restaurant is currently closed but there is a convenient store just across the highway   Large level area for tents. Price for RV with one person is 30 Q.

name: Auto Hotel Anthony
description: AC, Private parking, big tub for a bath also with shower head. Warm water. Cable TV. Quiet place and friendly staff. 200Q either from 8AM to 8PM or 8PM to 8AM.

name: Piscinas Artesanales Pa´Siwan
description:
This is a quiet “large” parking lot (8 vehicles) at the end of the road (on a hill) good for small Vehicles (no rigs).
It is next to a forestal park where you can do zip-line in 4 different stations through the “jungle/ mountain” (25Qz)
We spent one night and it was very quiet, it was just us, and the police patrol came by a couple of times, but did not talk to us. There is a security guard. There is also several wc rooms (sanitarios) in a small yellow building at no cost. this is part of the centro eco Turistico and they have swimming pools further down with slides.. 
it was fun, but water is cold in every pool and also in the showers.. (that’s where we went to relax and when we asked if we could stay over there, they told us to come here better. )

name: Texaco
description: we stayed here one night, arrived around 6 pm and parked at the back next to some wooden chairs and concrete tables with nice plants and trees. The owner lives here so we practically parked in his property, you can also park in front of his house. there's a big field with cows just behind. It was noisy at first but the gas station closes at nine and the Super24 at ten after that it was very quiet and very safe.

name: Buena Vista
description: Nice quiet place that belongs to a small cafe, a corner shop and a ice cream shop. It has nice showers and toilets. And very fast wifi available from the corner shop if you just buy something there. Prob not accessible for big rigs since the entry is kinda small. Overal nice relaxing place and close to the beach. We paid $6 per night for two people. There is also enough shade  provided by nice palm trees :)

name: santa Domingo el Cerro (free shuttle)
description: many free exhibitions plus fancy restaurants. views of volcanos and Antigua.  a very nice and safe place to relax. get the free bus from hotel santa Domingo. that's a great place to explore too for free (except a few exhibitions)

name: Hotel santa Domingo (free ruins)
description: nice convent free entry. there are a few paid exhibitions but most of it is free. free toilets. free shuttle to their art exhibition up the hill with views. very nice and lots of security. see photo for free bus times. much safer than the public mirador

name: Playa Casa Americas Itzá
description: Gorgeous bit of paradise, with access to a private section of the lake. Caretakers are Silvia and Alvin who live above, but keep to themselves. Great place to swim and relax under shade after some days on the road. We stayed three nights, and were initially quoted 25Qpp but negotiable. Slept with the sounds of the lake and beautiful cool breeze, very few mosquitos while we were there. Highly recommend.

name: Cajero 5B
description: 45Q fees with a DKB card. We withdraw 2000Q and that was the maximum.

name: PUMA Self Service 1Q cheaper
description: At this gas station you'll pay 1Q per gallon less if you fill up the tank by yourself. As it's the first gas station in Guatemala for us, I'm not sure if that goes for other gas stations as well.

name: Las pozas lake
description: Nice, quiet and beautiful spot to stay for the night, for us was great!! Free!! Safe!!!

name: Hotel Don Juan Matalbatz
description:
simple, no frills but friendly service. only reason I am adding them into iOverland is because of the 9' ceilings for the garage/courtyard. it's only the 2nd time in central America my 8'6" tall rig has comfortably fit under a roof in a hotel. you could probably negotiate parking fee if you decide to take a bus to semuc Champey from here.

restaurant is fair price but not so tasty. highly rated in Google and hostelworld

name: Laguna las Pozas
description: Beautiful spot to spend a night on the lake.  Locals here doing their laundry all along the shore on wash rocks. Breeze blowing perfect for the night.  UPDATE: the lake is where the village does their laundry during the day, in the evening the men come to bathe. We were charged 10Q when we left..

name: Road mending fee
description: A man with a rope across the road  stopping all traffic & asking for money.  He asked us for Q100, we gave him Q10 & a cold coke. He was repairing the road.

name: Super pet
description:
Very professional clinic! One doctor can speak very good English and very helpful! 
They are the doctor with license!

name: Sticker HD Printing Shop
description: Pulled over to make a phone call and realized we were right out front an HD print shop. The owner is so kind and professional! We got vanwives for the back of our van and 200 stickers (9$ for 100 stickers!) we’ve wanted to do this for a while!!! Took 15 minutes.

name: Brake Burner!!!!
description: OMG! Unbelievably STEEP descent. Paved road but think twice before coming down this tight road. No places to pull out to let the brakes cool. We used 2nd low range gear with full engine brakes. And crawled down approx 8km.

name: Soccer field
description: Just across the soccer field is a spot where the canoes are placed near the lake. We stayed the night here

name: Shell
description: Shell station with super, regular and low sulpher diese

name: Toy 4 Boys - Drone repair
description:
THIS GUY IS AWESOME. 

Happy and knowledgeable 

So professional and fast!! He has direct connections for anything DJI as well. He ordered in parts to fix our mangled drone from Miami and woke up at 4 am to come to the office early to have it fixed before we left Guatemala City at 7 am.

YIPPIE! “Brand new” drone.

We also purchased a DJI gimbal with him. Got it the same day. 

+502 5203 2335

name: Kombi and bolcho club
description: Great guys  (Lico) helped me out with my Kombi. Have lots of used parts for beetles and Kombi. Also able to get new parts

name: ATM 5b
description: One of the few atms in the neighborhood ......

name: Shell station next to parque central
description:
Shell station with regular diesel, super 95, and regular 91

The shell station has 2 duchas and 2 toilets

name: Camping in the parque central next to shell
description:
Next to the shell station the is the Central Park. The park is a semi flat spot with some threes. There are two duchas and a toilet at the shell station, not yet sure if it stays open at night.

Police in town told it was fine to stay the night here(border was closed on Sunday afternoon)

Later at night the owner of shell station dropped by including some Metropolitan police, he told this is private area. He asked 25Q to stay the night and use the facilities. No problem we payed and he wishes us good night.

name: Tropigas
description: Good option for filling tanks. they were able to fill our cylinders and had the adaptors for the internal tank as well. only took cash payment.

name: Mountain Nest
description:
MODERATOR NOTE: Rejected - must be generally available without reservation

This is a sweet cabin in the mountains with a spectacular view. Remy and Darina live on the top half of the property and love hosting travelers/overlanders. They are great company. It’s situated in an area where the village people speak an indigenous language called Q’eqchi, they are friendly and always seemed happy to stop and stare/wave :) Carlos, the caretaker, is very friendly and helpful, in front of his house is where you will park your rig and walk the 200m to the cabin. We were invited to have lunch at Carlos’ house with the hosts where his wife made a delicious spicy soup. The entire atmosphere of the area is magical. You should definitely come here. You can find the listing on Google or Airbnb (I’ve pasted it below too). It is a 45 minute drive to Semuc Champey. The road to the cabin is only accessible by 4x4, it’s steep and rocky and definitely washed out in some areas. Staying here was the perfect dose of peace & quiet to getaway from road travel.  


https://abnb.me/a574i74PSab

name: Agua Pura En-Gadi
description: Agua pura fill up window/store. Filled our 7 gallon tank for 6Q. Wide enough street to park our Tacoma. Nice family and people!

name: Turismo Laguna Brava
description:
Blue building on the left as you enter Aguacate. Stop here to pay for entrance to Laguna Brava. Q25pp for nationals and Q50 for foreigners. They’ll give you a ticket and tell you to go to the next blue building down the road and that’s the the road you’ll follow to the parking area.

Getting there: road is rocky and steep, you’ll need 4x4 & some clearance. It may be passable without during the dry season. Right now it’s still wet and feeling the remanence from Hurricane Iota & Eta. 

There are 3 places you can park. The mirador, the 1st parking area and the 2nd parking area closer to the Laguna. Getting to the 2nd parking area is not advisable by the locals BC it’s steep and wet in some areas but we saw pick up trucks do it. We parked at the mirador to sleep (no charge) and drove down to the 1st parking area then walked down to the Laguna to take a boat ride to the cenotes and waterfall. We negotiated Q500 for 2 people and a dog for the boat ride. Beautiful and worth it! There are cabins/rooms in cabins available or tent camping on a flat area next to the Laguna as well. Not sure what the charge is. 

If you don’t have 4x4, ask the guys at the turismo office if you can arrange for a ride down to the Laguna, we saw locals with pick up trucks full of people to drop off. Also- try to arrange to come during the week! Very crowded on the weekends.

name: CODACA Hino Dealer
description: Toyota Hino Dealer, only work on big rigs/trucks, sell parts for big trucks please note 7500kg over are big trucks. Great crew luis the manager and Pablo and little luis looked after my truck and did amazing job sourcing parts. as Mercedes was of no help

name: Sitio Arqueológico El Ceibal
description:
Archeological site. Dirt road. Cost 5Q for nationals, 60Q foreigners

Sitio arqueológico con muchas estelas y dos estructuras. El camino para llegar es de terracería. La entrada cuesta 5 quetzales para nacionales y 60 quetzales para extranjeros.

name: SHP Laundry
description:
Wash and dry Q6 per pound. Ready the same day. Staff was very friendly and clothes smelled good after wash. They are open 7AM to 6:30PM every day.

Lavado y secado a Q6 por libra. Todo listo en el mismo día. Los encargados fueron muy amables y la ropa olía muy bien. Abierto de 7:00AM a 6:30 PM todos los días.

name: Villa del Profe
description:
Large grassy land for all sizes of Camper.
Big rigs are welcome.
75Q/night.
Excellent wifi.
10 minutes walk from Castillo de San Felipe.

name: selina hostel
description:
this place is awesome!
very lage hostel.
clean and nice atmosphere. 
i had the place for myself 
because of the covid epidemic. 
there is a very large indoor parking.
10$ for a dorm.
they have a pool and a bar.

name: Iximché
description: Mayan ruins. Guatemala's first capital. Thanks to the english speaking guide it was a great experience.

name: Hotel Oxib Peck
description: We tried other options before coming here and everybody denied us. The guys here received us very well! For 50 quetzales we slept inside the car, used a toilet, a shower and WiFi. Felt very safe inside the parking lot. Only for small rigs.

name: Hacienda Del Café
description:
It's actually a boutique coffee farm that has an amazing accommodation with amazing facilities at a reasonable price.
And if you're into coffee, you hit jackpot.
The owner is very friendly welcoming and willing to help.

name: Purificadora
description:
So hard to find a purificadora around here for some reason. Water tastes good and the guy said it’s free! They filled our 20liter/5gallon jerry can three times. 

The street is tight so in our van we had to repark for a bigger vehicle but most cars got by.

name: Centro Recreativo Chixot
description:
We wanted to see the natives paintings of comalapa. We saw this place next to the road. Nice grassy area, with swimming pool, toilets but no shower.
30q the night or the day for 2 persons.

name: Acqua Life
description: They filled our 5 gallon or 20L jerry can for 10Q. It’s in a gated shopping center with a guard but he just waved us through.

name: Purificadora
description:
They have garrafones. filled our jerry can.

10Q for 5 gallons or 20 liters

They don’t have a sign so keep an eye out for a place with a big silver metal garage door and blue overhang. The door will be open

name: Sipacate Tranquilo
description:
Nice, clean and shaded spot right on the beach. A few families on the weekends, they all left after sunset. There are garbage cans that ~most~ people use. Police passed by but only to make sure everything is safe. There is a restaurant across the road with inexpensive food. They also have bathrooms and showers. The bathrooms are free and the showers are only 5Q. 
There are streetlights that stay on all night. So even when you head to the beach at night you can see your stuff.  We stayed in our van and our friends pitched a tent.  Perfect place! Just after sunset the mosquitos go wild for a little bit but the rest of the time it’s not bad. 
The road is dirt but fine with 2WD.

name: La Mojarra Dorada
description: Very Good little restaurant to est fresh fish. They have fish in a pool and They prepare it directly. Mojarra costs 40Q

name: Comedor Selenita
description:
Amazing food. BBQ beef or chicken, and served on a plate with beans, rice, green onions, and macaroni salad.
2 plates and a drink for 55Q. Great value and great food. Good size parking spot right in front of the restaurant.
Comes with free WiFi. 
Clean bathrooms and great service. Definitely recommend.

name: Shell Gas station
description:
A big Shell Gas station with 1 cold shower and 2 toilets.
It's between the shop/restaurant and the car wash service. 
The stuff and the owner (with shaved head) are very friendly and helpful.
We used the showers while staying overnight (on the weekend).
Some big buses stay there overnight too. So it can be loud, because they come and go during the night. 
There are cameras installed, but the lights will be switched off after the stuff leave (even though the owner told us, that they are switched on the whole night). 
We felt safe, but hadn't got a good sleep at all, because of the loud busses and the smell of their engines, which they switch off very late after arriving.

name: Chortiz
description: We arrived in this litle mountain village just after sunrise. We asked a local if we could stay somewhere for the night - brought us to the caretaker of the cabin. The cabin had not been used for almost a year because of covid-19, but both the cabin and the bed linen were clean. There were a single bed, a double bed and a bunkbed and extra blankets for cold nights. Outside is a water tap which we used for cooking and drinking after filtering it. The toilets are next to the school building. The price was 20 or 25Q per person, I don't remember it exactly.

name: Gasolinera con lavado gratis
description: Gaz station where they wash your car for free. They did it very well si Wenger let them a tip. Nice guys!

name: La Casa Del Resorte
description:
Very helpful Mechanics Shop specializing in suspension for large rigs, but they were very willing and helpful to replace our driveshaft universal joints quickly. 

All hands on deck when we arrived, 3 men  worked together to remove the 2 piece shaft with 3 u-joints, inspected everything and replaced the failed joint with a quality part in under 2 hours.

name: Pool at Finca El Pillar
description:
Outdoor swimming pool called El Paraíso Azul located at the Finca El Pillar terrain. The entrance is Q25 per person.
The water is not heated so prepair for a fresh swim and shower. They have a 1m, 2m and 3m deep pool. There are flush toilets with paper on site. In the weekends it can be bussy with locals and there will be food vendors.
You can also rent MTB to go up to a viewing point and back. 
We took a Q30 mototaxi from the other side of the city to get here (but we probably could have got a better deal). Just say Finca El Pillar and they will know where it is.

name: Hotel Francelia
description:
First of all: if you don't need to go to Escuintla, don't go.
The city is chaotic, dirty and it was the only place in Guatemala where we felt unsafe.

Hotel Francelia is okay. We slept with four people in a room with two matromonial beds Q250 in total. The shower is cold and the rooms hot. There is no real sitting area inside or outside. The outdoor area, which is also the parking lot for the hotel, is covered by a sort of sunscreen, but still can be very hot. The wifi is fast.

name: Vet Pro
description: What a great place to take your cat or dog. English speaking vets that took great care of our stray kitten. They provide vaccinations, flea treatment, de-worming, and sell high-end, imported food for both cats and dogs. 815Q for the full treatment including a bag of dry food. Perhaps not the cheapest vet in the country, but a very professional service.

name: Autobahn
description:
Really honest, tidy and very capable place for all kinds of auto repairs. 

We stopped here to ask for a tool we needed to change a part on our car.
The owner Camilo was very helpful, lent us the tool and let us do the repair inside his workshop.

As it turns out, Camilo has studied in Germany and speaks good German.
He and his experienced mechanics helped us with several problems we ran into during our repair.

Camilo did not charge us anything and did not even want to accept a tip but told us to give the money to his mechanic.

We would come here again with any mechanical problem.

name: Crater Azul
description: This is the parking lot for Crater Azul when turning off of the PET 12 and driving through fincas. The turn is not marked. Look for a tiendita almost directly North of this gps spot. It’s next to the dirt road where you’ll turn. There’s a ranch house behind the tiendita. At the house the family will charge you to drive through their fincas. We were quoted Q30pp to drive through the fincas to access Crater Azul, Q100 for access + camping (for 2 people), negotiable.
