The family is very friendly and will answer any questions you have about Crater Azul. You’ll drive through several livestock gates that you’ll have to unlatch and re-latch as you pass. The road is a bit rutted out but we saw a local van make it. High clearance will be helpful, but not necessary. It looks like it’ll get muddy when it rains. Not suitable for big rigs due to the low tree branches and a narrow, wooden plank bridge. We came in a 2.5m tall Toyota Sequoia. Flat, shaded parking spaces, trash cans, a pit toilet (just a hole in the ground) with plastic sheet walls on 3 sides. You can make a fire for grilling; there’s wood around. Crater Azul is actually a spring (not a crater) with crystal clear water. It’s very pretty and good for swimming. It looks more beautiful when it’s clean, but after busy days there can be lots of trash around. It can get overcrowded on weekends and holidays, as boats of people also come from Sayaxche. Mostly National tourists. Recommend visiting during the week. Bring everything you need, including insect repellent. Claro signal unreliable/spotty.

name: El Cuartito
description: Breakfast, lunch, and dinner. Artsy, relaxed atmosphere with nice people. Local beers, too! Food is international (didn't eat, only had beers which were good). only open until 8:00, though....

name: Panaderia Masa Madre
description: Very high quality bakery. Absolutely delicious sourdough boule for 20q  and they have some tools and cookies, too (but the sourdough, oh my, the sourdough). No cakes or things like that, but the bread is stellar.

name: Don Arturo
description:
Asked if we could stay and they said yes like this was not the first time. I would almost assume that most Don Arturo's offer camping, because we have stayed at others before.

15q for the van, we could park behind the store (away from traffic), and they asked for my name and phone number.

Good option if you're looking for a place late in the day and heading out the next morning.

name: La Cuevita de los Urquiza
description: This place just waits for tourists to rip them off and should be avoided for the plethora of other fantastic fare this town has to offer. All plates are 80 Q for food that is average at best. And the waiters will try to add extra charges for no reason and then tell you that the bill does not include tip.

name: Laguna Beach
description: Restaurant and swimming pool with a large grassed area

name: Aguateca nacimiento (spring)
description:
This is the swimmable source of a river with crystal clear, 24⁰C water. It's also the trailhead for the Aguateca ruins (guided 45 mins on foot one way). During weekends, families come here to swim, BBQ and drink. There are toilets, picknick tables, palapas and fire pits. It's in the jungle, with the fauna that comes with it (birds, mammals, insects).

The last stretch of track is not on Openstreet-, nor on Google- nor on Apple maps. Have your GPS guide you to an unpaved road that starts North in between the residential blocks in Las Pozas but then goes North-west. By the time you're close to the waypoint, look out for a track on your right (that is not on the map), with a white, bulletholed and completely faded sign. Follow it, take a left after you've opened (and closed) a barb wired fence. The track can be muddy and two wheel drivers left their vehicle just before the last water/mud pool.

Claro LTE coverage.

Original: We found this place looking for the aguateca ruins. It’s a small dirtroad on your right if your coming from Las Pozas. It has a big white sign in front if the road that says aguateca. It’s a beautiful awesome place with alot of mayan history. We camped right next to the river where we could hear the monkeys howl all day. The river is great for bathing and connecting with the local community. If you want to hike to aguateca it’s 100q for the guide and 20q per person to enter the ruins. For camping its 25q per person. And you can basically put you tent, van or hammock anywhere you want. Definitely a place that i would recommend if you want to experience jungle life!!

name: El Naranjo Mayan site
description:
Awesome site, which is currently being dug out of the jungle by a crew of 140 people.! Only a couple of temples / buildings are free, but to see it this 'rough' was quite special to us.Don't skip the 'tree house' at the end of the park! 

We camped at the campamento, about 2km from the site. Free with showers, toilets and safety.

Road to here was quite rough, but doable with high clearance in 2wd. Rainy season will be be pretty challenging but think it will be doable as it's mostly rocky ground. Ask directions at Melchor de Mencos as none of our navigations was able to find it. The road from Yaxha to here was overgrown and not accessible. 

Entrance fee was included in the one for Yaxha and Nakun, 80Q.

name: Reserve at Hearts In Action
description:
"Hearts in Action" is a great place to stop by and check out. (best to call ahead +50252012959)
We thought to stop by for an afternoon, and ended up staying 5 days, soaking up their positive energy, helping with a project or two, and enjoying their endless stream of new ideas. Great stop on your way to El Mirador, or to be in a remote area and still go to the lake in a hot afternoon.
Suzanne and Mario (+1 8327039005 in case you need English, whatsapp prefered)  have a thriving wood carving business on site (Itza Wood), a jewelry workshop, artisanal products, and a pretty impressive hydroponics experiment site (where you can camp as well).
 
They're also looking to expand into tourism with a nice 6p cabana (on Airbnb), restaurant (delicious food!) and various camping options around the farm, all with pristine toilets. 
You can camp next to their house and be close to the sites activities and wifi, or you can camp in the middle of the jungle in total solitude.  It's an 800 acre/320hectare beautiful farm with hiking trails, birding, organic gardens and a bee farm, sure there will be a spot for your rig.. ;) As they've been here for a long time, they can arrange all kinds of local guides, hikes, tours as well.

name: Main Plaza
description: Safe place to sleep. Very Clean, with bathroom beside church - 3 quetzal to use. We talked with the Police  to ask for permission. Ok

name: Distribuora universal
description: Huge parking lot next to the collectivo boats. Seemed safe to us, friendly people, parked here for 3 days/2 nights. Paid 80q.

name: PA Autos -  Alienacion
description: Friendly staff with Good knowlodge. We aligned our defender 110 tyres here. Good machine too. Recommended

name: Comedor Katampe - Mercado central
description:
Good lunch and cheap 20q churrasco with juice. 
Recomended.

name: Antojitos Salvadorenos
description: Good place to pupusas tasty. 10-12 Q. Juices 12-15 Q. Recomended.

name: cascadas de Santa Avelina
description: Nice cascadas, nothing super spectacular, but quite remote and unvisited. The drive in these regions is very nice, lots of small towns, indigiounous people and colorful dresses. No absolute need for 4x4, but a bit of clearance will help.

name: Hotel y Restaurante Puertas Del Cielo
description:
We have got to this hotel through google search, we called to ask if they have parking place and they approved.
When we arrived, a woman came to open a gate lock in front of the hotel which can contain around 3 RV.

The restaurant has affordable price and good food, the room is small but really enough for a refreshment and the shower is good.

name: New place for ticket to PN Pacaya
description:
They are charging you here now. If you don't to National Park don't pay (they get crazy with this). We just visite the villages because this we didnt pay. 
IF you go to NP, you can pay in the others entrance of iOvernalder . A lot of guides Will Try to charge you.

name: Finca Campo Alegre (JOB)
description: JOB is a nice guy that are planing to do a campsite here, completly wild and beautyful. Here is the Best of the lava and The volcano Pacaya. The to this point is very narrow, but we did with our defender 110. The maximum height is 2. 4m, but you can go to another site with better way. Call him in the vilage Patrocínio and figure out The Best place to Camp. Phone +5025938-8847

name: Hotel Mansion - Villa Residencial
description:
This place is the worst. We only stayed there because it was somewhat close to the border, we were exhausted from entering from Mexico and it has good reviews.
It is located in a sketchy and dumpy neighborhood. I know this is Central America but this neighborhood is extra shady. The food the hotel restaurant is overpriced rubbery meats. They charged us more than the price listed in the lobby. During heavy rain water came into the room underneath the door. They kept telling us to keep quiet even though we were just reading and chilling with no music or tv; and even though they put us in a room next the the street where dogs were barking nonstop. 
After we showered we used the towels to dry ourselves and used the wet towels to wipe up the water on the floor. It rained heavily and water got into the room. As we were leaving the manager berated us and told us we need to pay Q300 for the two towels. She claimed the towels were left unusable. We tried to reason with her but she became more angry. So finally we gave her Q300. This place is the worst. Don’t let the positive reviews fool you.

name: Taller y Servicentro Fauggier
description: Knowledgeable and professional staff. They quickly diagnosed a coolant leak and replaced a hose and two clamps for Q310. Jorge, the owner is a friendly guy. He gave a ride back to where we were staying so we didn’t have to wait with the van. He was genuinely interested and curious about our travels and gave us advice on how to travel through Guatemala safely. He even called us after we left the next day to make sure the van was running fine.

name: Stadium of Tactic
description: Quiet during the week. A little bit noisy during the week-end. Police come to see if all good. Stay few days. Safe and secure.

name: Taller Ruiz
description:
Small road side mechanic. He doesn’t have a lift but has a covered working area. Helped us fix a stuck brake caliper and flushed the brake fluids. He also diagnosed a misfiring cylinder and calibrated the distributor. At KM98 on CA8, just past Puente San Francisco on the way to Jalpatagua. His number is:
+50248291066

name: Miratenango
description:
A nice campsite from where you can start the hike as well. Can also leave your car here. Probably they can arrange guides, but we didn't ask.
Way up is doable for every car, the access gate might be a bit tight for bigger rigs.
We paid 150Q for 2 cars, 4 adults and 2 kids.

name: PCR test site
description: Cheapest we could find, 560Q per test. Needed it to cross the border with El Salvador. You can park here, and do the test next to the parking lot. Good service, possible to pay with cards.

name: Grupo E
description: Easy to find but in any case... now it’s on the map... still looking for Grupo F&H!

name: Grupo A exact location
description: We walked the whole thing but with a half decent car you could probably drive all the way to the car park. (Best done with high clearance, definitely not with an RV!)

name: Imperial Okan Aarin
description: The only place open to eat in town while we were there. Simple maya kitchen with a couple cold drink options, pretty cheap. No menu just what she has on the day! Highly recommend checking out the small village/area. Lots of farm animals running around

name: La Bodegona full stock supermarket
description:
Well priced, where the locals buy their supplies and alcohol.
Comprehensive range of everything

name: El campo
description:
Basket ball and football field.
More or less quiet. Calm and safe. 
Best spot in this town. Close to Coban. On the way of lanquin(semuc champey )

name: Municipal stadium
description: Front of the stadium...basic place ,no special view ...but quiet and safe ...more good of street parking

name: Parking of a private hospital
description:
We arrived late in Huehue and asked the police where we should park for the night. He suggested this place. We went at the end of the narrow road and then down to a big empty field.
We spent a super quiet night but at 6 am the security guy told us we had either to leave or pay for the parking. As it's not easy to find a place in Huehue we recommend this. The police is nearby so it's super safe. It might be a bit difficult to get there with big rigs because the road is narrow and there's a steep downhill to the parking lot. Ok with 2wd vehicles.

name: Fábrica de Cerámica
description: Small shop full of the local pottery, all hand painted and glazed. Since this is where it’s made it’s cheaper than all the other towns on the lake. Friendly owners, large selection, shame we couldn’t take any with us.

name: San Antonio Market
description: Decent size market, under cover, worth a visit if in the area... also good photo opportunity place.

name: El Rincon de las Crepas
description: Nice crepes and coffee! They have a whole selection of coffees and crepes along with other postres.

name: Seven waterfalls
description: Very nice swimming holes ans small waterfall. Easy accès by tuk tuk and 30 min easy walk or get dropped from a man ha. Entrave is 20 Q pp. really worth it

name: Robberies
description:
UPDATE: road is fixed. See 03FEB2023 update

CAUTION: this is the section where the armed robberies take place... best to ask for a police escort in either town.

There is a steep 3km rough section here, clearly hasn’t been maintained in a long time! If going west (from Santiago to San Pedro) you’ll going uphill which might be doable in a high clearance 2WD IF it’s dry (I wouldn’t recommend trying it) in any case high clearance strongly recommended if your care about your undercarriage. 
Going in the opposite direction (downhill) high clearance 2WD should do the trick.

name: By the river
description: Best spot, clean for one time, front of the river, no garbage, no noise...

name: Boat tours to Aguateca or crater azul
description: Here starts boats tours to Aguateca, crater Azur, Ceibal or las Pilas. Lazaro is a fantastic guide., Very reliable and honest. We did Aguateca one day and the second morning crater Azul and rio Negro. Both were fantastic , saw crocs, terapins, birds and swam in incredible clear and blue water. Price 700 for 2 as a private group, 150 pp if more than 5. If you are not afraid of mosquitoes you can stay here too- next to the river, safe and fairly level. Enough space for a few campers. His number is +50232143613.

name: Free Covid test
description: At the hospital of antigua you can get free fast antigen covid test. It’s only until 11:30 am. You can take it if you are a tourist and they give you the result immediatly.  Is also pet friendly because it’s an outside testing clinic so you can take your dog with you.

name: Casa Museo
description: Small museum just across from the church, free entry open everyday. By small I mean 15-20mins you can see everything. The friendly host gave us a tour explaining the locals customs and history around the lake, asked a small donation at end

name: laboratorio clinico biologico
description:
Covid test lab.just up the hill 50m from the bus stop
950q for PCR test, 24 hour wait for results
650 for quick test
Results sent via email

name: Puma fuel station
description: Flat area for trucks just behind the pumps. Outdoor shower and loo at gable end of shop. Pay 20q for the facilities. My vehicle is self-contained so I paid zilch. Safe at night, quiet enough.

name: Hotel Pasabien
description: We asked the woman in the reception if we could park here for the night (camper truck  2 ppl) She had to call someone first but eventually we payed a parking fee of 20 quetzales to stay in their gated parking space. There are some toilets but we didn't ask for water or electricity, so not sure about that. There is a pool at the hotel, which we also didn't use as we just asked to park. Very nice and lots of space

name: La Ceiba Hotel and Resort
description: Called ahead to ask if we could stay for the night before crossing the border in the morning. Reception lady was very friendly. cost was 50 qtz per person with showers, toilets, fast wifi and pool. Water available on resort parking. Don't know about electricity as we didn't ask for this. Height limitation is 3, 20 on the hotel gate. The resort gate is higher.

name: Gasoline Station/Oil change
description:
We did Oil change here, for our RV with a Ford motor. We Asked to the Gasoline Station next to the bridge, a friendly man did it. We gave him a “propina”.
Notice that we had bought our oil before, because it was 5W30 one.
There is a nice restaurant next to, where we spent the night too. Nice staff.

name: For those who like tough roads...
description: Pretty sweet view, fun dirt road, super steep for those who are into this sort of things... 4x4 and motos only.

name: Tigo shop to buy SIM card
description:
You can buy a SIM card from Tigo here for Q10. Bring your passport. Don't get tricked into buying a plan (that's what they'll try to sell you). Go to tigo.com.gt and check out the prepaid options (prepago). I got the SIM for Q10 plus a prepaid packet for Q120 that includes calls/sms and 12G internet for 30 days. If you're staying for only a few days or weeks there are cheaper "paquetes" that you can buy.

The Tigo shop is part of the "Zentro Plaza", which includes a supermarket, ATMs (5B and BI), restaurants, and small shops.

name: Natura Spa
description: 30 minutes sauna + showers for Q50 per person. The sauna can fit two, so by paying 50 each you get 1 hour of it. It looks like they are just getting started so it's new and clean. They have another address in Zona 1 that appears on Google maps, but they only have massages over there. Don't get mixed up. Phone number (and whatsapp) is +50255788907

name: Camping Ecological Park Casa Tzocomá
description:
Camping and RV park in Chichicastenango close to the market but in a very quiet and special area to camp and enjoy nature.

Available services:
RV Parking prices:
Q100 per vehicle per night with 1 passenger
Q150 per vehicle per night from 2 or 3 passenger; from 4 passenger an extra Q25 per person is charged. 
Q50 per accommodation per person per night (without vehicle), does not include tent (backpacker). 

Camping combo: 
Q80 rental of: tent + sleeping bag+extra blanket + accommodation , per night per person. 
Q15 sleeping bag rental per night ( doesn't include accommodation) 
Q35 tent rental per night.( doesn't include accommodation) 
Q7 blanket rental. 
Q35 laundry per measure. 
Q20 or Q10 campfire 

All services include:
- free Wi-Fi 
- Drinking water
- Bathrooms
- Shower with warm water
- Area to wash dishes
- Electricity
- Vehicle toilet discharge
- Bird watching
- Flora and fauna
- Healthy and relaxing environment
- Allowed to place hammocks and tents
- Pets Allowed
- Wide and flat land
- any size RV vehicles can be parked

name: Jade Museum
description: Free museum with a boutique at the end of the tour where you can buy jewelry. The guide that gave us the tour was excellent and made it really interesting. A great way to learn more about Mayan and Aztec culture. There is a workshop and they explain the process of working with Jade, the different types, colors, where it comes from, and so on.

name: Sanitarios Premium
description: Cold showers for 10Q, clean, but cold...

name: Parqueo Cenotes Own- Ajab
description: Permitted Camp site by Yalaurel Community. Located at the parking lot for visiting Cenotes. From this camp site to los cenotes de Own-ajab is a 30 min Hike.

name: Church and park
description: Nice park, big square, some food stalls, a church. Pretty quiet and chilled.

name: Playa El Chapeton
description:
Excellent quiet beach to spend days off, quiet and safe public beach. you meet friendly locals and they help you with whatever you need. 
Ask for Mamarre, who will help you with whatever you need.
.....
excelente playa tranquila para pasar días de descanso, playa pública tranquila y segura te encuentras con pobladores amables y te colaboran con lo que necesites. pregunta por mamarre es un personaje de la playa que te colabora con lo q necesites

name: Red Door: International Food Warehouse
description:
Got this tip from my Spanish teacher in town. It's the place where all the international restaurants buy their internal ingredients. The place is run by an English (?) guy and he drives to Guatemala city every week. Very good prices. Lots of cheese, meats and Italian products (as well as drinks / rums).

A bit hard to find: Next to a pharmacy is a red door. If the place is open there will be a sign "open / abierto" and you can knock on the door to get in.

They are open every day from 9:00-15:00 except Sundays.

name: La Estancia (bad!!)
description: Insipid food and they charge 20% propina (tip)... It's a tourist trap. The restaurant looks good and the food also looks good, but it's just canned food with a nice presentation.

name: Girasol garden
description: If you are into flowers, bees and such things this is a neat place to check out and take photos. Q10 to get in...

name: Cafecito Del Mar
description:
This is the location you probably hear other travellers talk about! Good coffee, small breakfast/lunch menu offering smoothie bowls, avo toast etc. Vegan&normal desserts, juices, cocktails and beer. Open 8am-3pm.
Check photos for current prices/options

name: ISAGAS
description: Closest fuel stop to El Ceibo. Small shop here and in Lagunitas village.

name: Monte Carmelo
description: Nice and wide campground, spots with shade and others with sun. Areas for barbacoa, a field of volleyball and soccer, playground for kids. Up in the mountains, they have opened a tunnel that crosses a small mountain in the property. They also rent small casitas with a bed bunk's Q30 pp. They offer bathrooms and showers. the showers are cold but if you talk to Erick, the guy that takes care of the place, he can show you a small house with a hot shower. So we stayed here one week and they charged us Q20 pp. we are two adults and two kids. they didn't charge us for the kids. We needed this place after border la Mesia and because we needed to fix our truck. You have access to water for your camper and also they sell water for drinking in the property in the small tiendita. Good option for Huehuetenango town.

name: Hotel Sheny
description: Cheap basic hotel. A local lady took us here and she managed a good price for us. We paid 150q for two people in one room. There is place for parking but its limited since there were alot of cars here. Was a good stop for one night at the border. Wifi in the room!

name: Shell.
description:
Shell. Opened Sept. 2021. 
Shop, toilets, no overnight parking. 
Unfortunately its position completely overpowers this small community.

name: Bici Abeja, Coban
description: The best bicycle shop in town. Good selection of parts and knowledgeable mechanic.

name: Playa Chechenal
description: A beautiful spot on the lakeside under the trees. Private beach. Day entry 5 Q + 25 Q to stay the night. They shut the gate to day visitors at 5pm so you have the place to yourself until they open at 8 in the morning. Flush toilets are very clean. The attendant allowed me to hook up to power at their kiosk. Road in is gravel but OK for medium sized rigs. Busy with family on weekends with competing stereos but they go by 5. Felt very secure. No showers but good spot to swim. BBQs. Everything is well maintained and clean. The kiosk sells drinks (beer, water, softdrinks)

name: Texaco. Nuestra señora de Guadalupe
description:
Large flat truck parking area. Not the quietest but good for one night. No shade.
Toilet. I was allowed to use staff shower. Not the cleanest but free.
Bar and snacks. Didn't ask about WiFi.

I wasn't charged to pitch a tent in the far corner.

name: Lotificación Ayutla
description:
Quiet roads in new housing development. Plenty of options. Best entrance is from road exactly opposite bus station.
Map marker is at small park that has tin roofed palapas, barbecue places with built in grids, trees and lawn. Nicely manicured.

name: Aldea La Barrona
description:
We arrived in the middle of the week the beach was quiet. It is a quiet and safe beach, but the cleanliness of the beach leaves much to be desired. You will find shower and toilet services. 

We parked next to the Rancho Margarita, the owner of the place. Don Francisco is very kind, on his property he has parking for $ 20 Quetzales. 
We had access to his bathrooms and drinking water to fill tanks. 

There is a turtle man, at night if you are lucky you can see the turtles that come to spawn. You must do your errand before arriving as you will only find small shops selling food and drinks.
The access road to get to the first kilometers has deteriorated pavement and the rest about 16 kilometers more is a dirt road, some parts better than others.



Llegamos en medio de semana la playa estaba sola,  es una playa tranquila y segura, la limpieza de la playa deja mucho que desear, encuentras servicio de duchas y sanitarios, nos estacionamos al lado del Rancho Margarita el dueño del lugar. Don Francisco muy amable , en su propiedad tiene parqueo a $20 Quetzales, tuvimos acceso a sus baños y agua potable para llenar tanques. hay un tortuga tío, de noche si tienes suerte puedes ver las tortugas que llegan a desovar. debes hacer tu mandado antes de llegar ya que solo encontrarás tiendas pequeñas lugares de venta de comida y bebidas.
La carretera de acceso para llegar los primeros kilómetros pavimento deteriorado y el resto unos 16 kilómetros más es de carretera de terracería algunas partes mejores que otras.

name: Surprisingly Peaceful Gas Station
description: Gas Station with parking away from the road. Got a good night's sleep before heading across the border to Mexico.

name: La Casa de Don David
description: Very nice restaurant with a view of the lake, amazing sunsets, and some cool stuff like a cable that transports food to the lakeside terrace, and bird feeders close to the dining area that are enjoyed by both exotic birds and iguanas! The food is good and reasonably priced. Fast wifi, power plugs at tables, and spotless bathroom. The owner is American and has lived in El Remate for 40 years!

name: Laboratorio medical PCR test
description: Closest place to the border to get a last minute fast PCR. Normally they say 4hrs but they had our ready in 40 minutes.

name: Guatemala to Belize
description:
This is an easy border crossing.
Fees:
30 to 50 Quetzals to cross the bridge (cash only).
8 to 12 Belize dollars for vehicle fumigation (cash only).
covid vaccine proof (not required anymore as of Feb ‘23)
30 to 60 Belize dollars for vehicle importation (cash or credit card). Except when card machine isn’t working. Plenty of money changers, but no ATM.

Hotel bookings no longer required (as of Feb ‘23). Edit: we were asked about hotel bookings 3 Times. Until the lady understood we live in a trailer. 

Visit belizing.com for official and up-to-date information.

name: Roadside Churrasco
description:
15Q per plate. Nice and convenient place for a quick stop to eat before heading to/from the Belize border. 

Friendly family service.

name: Hotel Finca Chijul
description:
Excellent camping spot, Q175.00 p / person, somewhat expensive but safe and good atmosphere.
---
Excelente spot de camping, Q175.00 p/persona, algo caro pero seguro y buen clima.

name: Parque Quetzali
description:
Little  town  Park north of San  Marcos next to  the road. 
30Q for camping. There  is  a parking  lot  but  we  parked on the  football field.

name: Hotel Villa de Don Andrés
description:
A nice hotel or B&B only one block from Parque a Centro America.
Owned & operated by a nice family 
Clean & quiet
I was able to park my motorcycle in their garage
Breakfast was nice
Wifi was fast & consistent

name: la casa rosa
description: great place to stay, many rooms and amenities, great view of the lake and super quiet

name: Tire repair shop
description: We stopped here after getting a really bad flat (sliced, not punctured) and had an amazing experience. The older gentleman and his young helper were great, they did a good sturdy internal patch and then swapped it out for our spare, done in an hour and cost us 150Q. Very enthusiastic and helpful with English speakers.

name: Lavandería Adnarim
description: we took our clothes here and they were returned with burnt patches and new dirty marks that weren't there prior. we took them back and she agreed to wash them again but I still wouldn't advise going here

name: Hotel del Sol (Cafe del Sol)
description: A rustic hotel on a black sand beach. I was only charged 250GTQ. They have reasonable WiFi, good parking and beautiful views.

name: Mirador Chuich Ok’ Ok’
description: Very beautiful mirrador with space for medium sized rig (we have a long sprinter). Longer than that it won’t fit in the very narrow road that goes up there. Decent bathroom available, lots of BBQ's, tables and seats to eat. No wifi but full LTE Claro signal. Had to negotiate, but could have it for Q50/pp per night. We didn’t do the Indian Nose trail as this spot has the same view, for cheaper, without the need to start the hike at 5am. Amazing sunset AND sunrise here !!

name: Mechanics Chay
description: Good Place, when you have trouble with your Rig doesn’t matter if it’s a small or big one. The Boss is super helpful and has a lot of experience.

name: Banrural atm - Cajero
description:
Atm here - seems easier to park and less of queue than the main shopping street. Wd 2000q no problema. 

//Its a 5 minute walk from border

name: La Chasah
description:
Good restaurant and Parking
Un bon restaurant à proximité des museo de la capitale

name: Las Tejas
description: Excellent restaurant. Road for Copan (Honduras). Big parking area.

name: Finca La Escondida
description: Excellent place for camping, have security, bathrooms, mini houses if you dont like camping. Jose is a security for the place, he is a nice person.

name: Rancho alegre
description: Very clean and open restaurant. They have a great menu and a family cooking food. Enough parking for big rigs. Clean washrooms and wifi to get work done

name: Farmacia El Ahorro
description: Alternative Place (pharmacy) to pay Guatemala TIP fee if Bank is closed. We arrived at Border the day after xmas so Bank was closed. So our helper took us to this place which is an agency for the Bank

name: Potable Water to refill your tank
description: Potable Water to refill your tank. 5 Qtz for 20 L. They wash your tank before refill it with potable water. You can stop in front (not big space but ok). Friendly and good service.

name: Tres Picachas
description: Very popular local swimming hole. Passed by on a Sunday afternoon and it was packed with cars down by the river, and several cars and even a school bus parked up on the road! Lots of people swimming and barbecuing by the water. Sign posted stating 5 quetzales pp ($0.66 USD) + 5 more quetzales for parking.

name: Big and quiet private parking
description: 100 meters away from road (still earing a little bit the noise of traffic but ok), you can park here for the night in a private parking closed at night. Flat, no shadow, ok just for one night on the road. A few trash. You probably can park your camper here for many days if you are going to Linvingston. Prizes started at 75 GTQ/day but we get it at 40 GTQ/night after bargaining and telling that we will leave at 8 am. Prize are 40 GTQ for day parking, 40 GTQ for nights, 80 GTQ for 24 hours. No services. Very friendly owner speak a very little english. Ask at restaurant at entrance.

name: Amazing balneario
description:
Wonderful Balneario, with waterslides, access to the river. We are cyclists and we were allowed to camp on the premises for 18Q, only Balneario is 12Q per person. Employees asked us for 30Q, but we agreed with the boss on 18Q, maybe because we arrived late 

Very quiet place at night.

name: Laundry Shalom
description: Full service 5Q per pound ready same day.

name: TECNISER Coban
description:
Very friendly mechanic ! They took time to find our problem, to check the whole engine. Then there was an educational where they explained all to us. I highly recommend going there, had issue on our Astro Chevy and made 2 others place before finding this one.
Charged us 200Q for everything.

name: La Torre supermercardo
description: This supermarket we think is better than one in town. Plenty of parking and other stores here too such as pharmacy

name: Aldea Canaán
description: Cell chips, phones, flashlight, chargers. Electronics

name: Autobel
description:
This family business (with Alfonso 'always there' Beltranena, his brother Ricky and their father) specializes in 'traditional' vehicles. The father has been here for 60 years, the sons all their life. There's a lot of mechanical knowledge in all of the people that work here. They're well connected and know where to source parts, quickly. Themselves interested in extended travel, this is a shop that won't treat you like "we'll never see this traveler again, so why bother?"

Alfonso uses WhatsApp, Messenger, but also Signal: +502 4646 9122. Spanish and a little English. Carmen responds to their email: autobel@hotmail.es.

name: Grutas de Cunen
description: Very nice place. we parked in front of a little house with a store. We paid Q15 for parking and Q15 for the night to sleep in our Camper. We had to walk 15 min down to get to the grutas. We paid Q15 for adults and Q10 for kids to enter the grutas. Nice natural water spring with natural pools.

name: Lavanda Guatemala
description: One of the best views at Lake Atitlan. It is a Lavender farm that does tours for 60Q per person including lavender tea and a yummy croissant. I also purchased some lavender honey that is absolutely delicious. The owners are a very nice french couple that also speak English. They also allowed us to stay overnight in our van. The parking is gated in so felt very safe.

name: Turismo y Guardabosques
description:
This the place where you register and pay for climbing Agua. Some pressure to book a guide for GTQ 350. We declined: the track is well marked with yellow arrows and dots. They want you to report back when you're done.

Parking is a problem in this town.

name: Guatemalan kids
description:
We craved a quiet spot on the beach, looked at satellite pictures and came here. It's at the far end of the village Champerico.

We were immediately invited to camp in one of three private back yards. We chose the one closest to the ocean. We were flocked by children who wanted to play, swim, boat-ride, catch crabs, cook, eat, share their parent's Ceviche with ours. (We did all that.) Parents and other villagers would come by and look at our vehicle. We were happy but exhausted after one afternoon.

Brace yourself: don't come here for peace and quiet.

Paid nothing, but shared all of our beer and soft drinks with the villagers.

name: El Viejo Café
description: Very good Coffee and bread from a swiss baker as well as the best wifi we had in the whole of Antigua

name: Acatenango tour - Asoava tours
description: Here is the location for the headquarters of asoava tours , they will take you up the volcano. It is cheaper than booking in Antigua. You can camp here the night and leave your vehicle while you go up the mountain. It is 4-5 hours up on the first day. They have tents without sleeping gear but mattresses are included. The view of Fuego volcano erupting is amazing. You walk down the next morning. Well worth the walk. Call Catalionos on What’s app: +502 5500 4707 for more information.

name: End of Franja Transversal del nrte
description: end of road. dont trust google maps.  road is fully washed out. use the road through yalanhuitz which is 4x4 high clearance track only..

name: solarguat.com
description:
Equipment for solar systems, excellent service, easy access, good prices and variety. They inform you well regarding installation.
Highly recommended.
We acquired lithium batteries 12V 200 AH

Equipos para sistemas solares, excelente servicio, fácil acceso, buenos precios y variedad. te orientan al respecto de instalaciones 
Recomendadisimos 
nosotros adquirimos baterías de litio 12V 200 AH

name: Lower slope of Chicabal
description:
This spot is on the side of secondary road leading to a small village below. It's public terrain (we asked several passerbys) and is used for camping by locals (fire pit, garbage (which we collected)). It is very visible. Leveling our vehicle was difficult.

We arrived at 2:00 pm, cooked and ate a meal (outside) and we were acknowledged by almost all (slow moving) traffic. The whole village must have known we were there. After sunset, the traffic died down but picked up again at 6:00 am. Nobody bothered us all night.

It may not be the best, but we chose this place because it's not as high (and cold or windy) as the ones nearer the top of Chicabal, which was hidden in clouds this afternoon.

Very poor Claro and Tigo signals.

name: Private jungle
description:
Before leaving Guatemala, we wanted to see Quetzals in trees (instead of wallets) but we were too late to camp at the Refugio.

This iOverlander waypoint is at a Tienda and restaurant, owned by entrepreneur Manuel (cell, WhatsApp: +502 4015 1551), who offered us a flat spot in the forest on his property (5 minutes by 4x4, high clearance and low gear, 15 minute walk from the Tienda). The site is easy to find at N 14.92993, W 091.87842, at 1713 meters altitude, but the road there is closed with a chain right behind the Tienda.

The camping area is not big and in between trees: shade all day. Quetzals to be seen in the trees. On Sunday, we hiked (with Manuel) to a mirador and a river. There's access to a waterfall which we did not visit.

Manuel enjoys the company of foreigners and likes to practice his English. He's thinking of developing the site and have bathrooms and more flat space.

name: El Tipo Gas Station
description:
Seems to be a brand new gas station (not visible on google street view). Open 24 hours with security. They let us stay the night. Leveled parking.
Litlle shop with possibly some food available and clean toilets. 
Gas station takes credit card.

name: Propane bottle refill
description: Propane bottle refill next to taller Autobel. There is a propane place that refilled my bottle/cylinder. We found it walking through the mechanic Autobel. But there must be an access from the road. Fair price.

name: Pronto Pizza
description: Very good pizza place for a very reasonable price. Pizzas from 60Q. I got a grande BBQ pizza for 80Q which would feed most groups of 2. Fresh cooked, ready in about 15mins

name: Hostal Casa Bethel
description: A clean, comfortable, cheap simple hostel, for 125 quetzals/person, room with private bathroom. Secure, locked  parking for motorcycles and a few cars in front. Close to El Calvario church up a hill, and walking distance to main square.

name: Hostal Casa Vieja
description:
Very nice, clean with A/C rooms for 190Q. Secure parking inside, huge patio with hammocks and fruit trees. Nice cafe/restaurant in the patio. Owner Leonel is so kind and helpful.
Electric shower, warmer water if you regulate for less water to come out.
Near bakery, pharmacy, grocery stores, and the main square. A nice stop before or after crossing the border with Honduras (60km). Big rigs won't have clearance to pass the entrance gate.Signs inside rooms say no pets are allowed.

name: Herrería el martillo en las palmas
description: Very good mechanic if you need a muffler he can fabricate one in no time for very cheap… we needed a new one and he charged us 60.00$ to do it and put it one.. very pleasant

name: cajero electrónico
description:
ATM for visa & mastercard in the shell fuel station, outskirts of Iztapa

servicio de cajero electrónico visa MasterCard en la gasolinera shel a las afueras de Iztapa

name: ATM Cajero 5B
description: Small ATM in a cage. 6$ fee, sometimes doesn't work I've heard, but was fine for me today. Also another ATM (same bank) on the corner inside a restaurant

name: Restaurante Tal vez Mañana
description: 2 floor restaurant, we were allowed to put our tents to lower floor for free and if we buy something drink and eat from the restaurant on the top floor. Local boy shared his internet via hotspot to us. Local beer was 10 quetzals.

name: Boat tours Boca del Polochic
description: Here the lanchas leave for the Parque natural Boca del Polochic. It's a nature reserve and you can see lots of monkeys (rio polochic), birds and manatees in the laguna de izabel. For lanchas you can call Pedro Jimenez (phone number 5122-4637) or ask in the office from the nature reserve at this coordinates (15.5238540, -89.3348960). Boat tour for 3 hours costs 350 Quezales per boat (doesn't matter how many you are, it's like a private tour). We saw several manatees in the lagoon and lots of birds and howler monkeys.

name: Te Quiero
description: nice little cafe with deliciously sweet coffee options and tasty croissants. basically all coffees that aren't plain black, 10q, were 15q for the small and 20q for the large. clean bathrooms and fast wifi.

name: Comedor Lucia
description: Small place with about 5 different dishes, 20Q each. We got the carne de res/pollo, and were both happy (pollo had a bit more meat than the res). Comes with small salad, some rice, and tortillas

name: Hotel El Eden
description:
105Q Very (very) basic place close to the airport (10mins) with decent wifi, double bed and private bath. 
Free private parking in entrance with locked gate, enough for 3 or 4 cars and several bikes.

Close to the airport but can't hear the planes. Back rooms of the hotel seem to still be under some sort of construction or renovation, 2 of the staff were using a grinder and other tools and the rooms were quite bare.

name: Grutas De Lanquin Cave
description:
Large cave recommended by Lonely Planet. 30Q pp, 10Q per vehicle to park. Self-guided or with guide. If there's no tours running the lights in the cave are off, so bring a Headlamp. Lots of little areas to explore with a river flowing out near the entrance

Tubing also available here, 35Q pp

name: Guatamaya Spanish Academy
description:
This school and homestay offers the best of both worlds- the option to be fully immersed in culture in a quiet, local neighbourhood, while also only a 5min walk from the busy touristy strip along the lake. The view from the classroom is amazing and keeps you motivated during class, and our teachers Rafael and Lorenzo did a great job at keeping class interesting by using a practical approach tailored to our needs. I stayed 2 weeks longer than originally planned, and convinced my Dad to join as well instead of going to Antigua, and we both couldn't be happier. The owner Jose also took the time to organize outings for us, including a cool tour to a nearby coffee plantation, where his family owns one of the plots. Everyone here is clearly very passionate about what they do, and it shows

Best reached through Jose on WhatsApp: 
+502 3332 7888
http://guatemayaspanishschool.org/

name: El Boqueron Canyon
description:
Interesting quick stop (~30mins) on a canoe-like boat paddled upstream by one of the locals through an impressive steep canyon. Also some tables, bano, and small playground by the parking area. Not to be confused with other Mayan area northeast of here with the same name.

Costs:
10q parking per vehicle
10q entrance pp
20q boat ride pp

name: El Mirador de Lanquin
description:
Nice hotel with, as the name suggests, a very nice view of the valley and mountains. 300q/night for 2 people, we got 500q for 2 nights. Room had 3 single beds, air con, and private bath.

Pool and restaurant on-site, with good portions and decent price- 35q for all breakfast dishes, 40q for all lunch/dinner dishes. We ate all our meals here for the 2 nights we stayed and all were tasty and filling

Lots of parking on the property, but a very tight uphill turn on the entrance, so big rigs will not make it. Haven't seen any secure parking in Lanquin, but felt comfortable to park our 2 motos next to the hotel as this property is fairly secluded 

Only negative was the laundry. They did a good job and same-day, but charged 10q/lb. If you talk about price before doing it, you could probably get a much better price

name: Pozas Machaquila (blue river for swimming)
description:
Cool stop to split up the drive between Flores and Rio Dulce, or vice-versa. Crystal clear river to swim in with a little current that's fun to drift down. Only locals here, no sign for this entrance and totally free. 

On the north side of the bridge from the highway, there's a sign to a different set of pools on the river, with some small palapas and concrete steps down to the river, may have to pay to park here. 

We preferred the pools on the south side of the river because it was fully natural and a bit more of an interesting swimming area

name: Beware Cajero Bi ATM
description:
Tried to withdraw 2000q from the Cajero Bi ATM here today, and after selecting the amount, the ATM stated "Processing your transaction" for a couple minutes before spitting out my card and giving no money, receipt, or prompts. 

On my banking app I could see 2000q was taken from my account. Thankfully about 10mins later my bank automatically canceled and refunded the transaction, but created a bit of stress for that time. 

There's a Cajero 5B ATM right beside which worked fine, so maybe stick to that one

name: Qumarkaj
description: The ancient ruins of the Quiche, mostly unrestored, beautiful, still in use by the local indigenous. I recommend the cave towards the back. Look up the history, it’s very interesting too. 30q to enter

name: Vulcano Tajumulco
description: Ask locals before driving up for hikes to volcano if its safe. When we were here today and asked about sleeping up there the locals said they have a lot of problems at the time and its dangerous. You could also here people shooting.

name: Automotriz Byron
description: Our Mercedes 308 had a problem with the ignition coil and the interrupter from the distributor. We couldn’t start the engine anymore. Byron (mechanic) could find and solve the problem. He could even find a new interrupter for the distributor for our old (1981) Mercedes, which is usually a big deal. He also organized a safe place to stay overnight because we couldn’t fit in his garage.

name: municipal camping
description: just before the agencies place there is a terasse where you can put your tent. 4 to 6 tents max. we arrived at 13hr so we can choose the spot and had the chance to be in front of el fuego.

name: Purificadora
description: 5Q to fill our 7 gal tank and they even cleaned our tank for us. Quick and friendly.

name: Azafran Panaderia
description: Takeaway bakery with seriously delicious sweet and savoury empanadas, cakes, and bread. I tried the piña empanada and the banana bread, both delicious. 5 to 6 quetzal each. it's in the mall right in front of the supermarket entry.

name: El Buen Gusto
description: Nice restaurant with 25Q+ breakfast, 35Q+ pizza, 40Q+ dinner (menu pics attached). Fast Wi-Fi and nice bathrooms, nice shady spot.

name: Cerveceria 14
description: one of the best breweries we have come across in a long time. huge campus with grassy areas and many tables. very friendly staff and everyone speaks English. incredible beers and food. prices for food was 65q for a burger to 100q for pizzas and beers ranged from 27-35q. american expats own and brew here and have setup a very familiar feeling American style brewery. it feels like we could be in Pacific North West again and not surrounded by volcanoes in Guatemala. they offered to let us stay in our van for free overnight in a shady area of the parking lot, but no access to amenities once they closed. this place is pretty far out of town with nothing else to do so it was a nice offer but we opted to stay at Verde Eventos that was very nice.

name: Las Antorchas - Swiss restaurant
description:
A very good restaurant situated in a nice patio. The chef is Swiss (from the French Speaking part), proposing delicious Swiss dishes (raclette, röstis, émincé de veau à la Zürichoise & meringues) as well as meat & pizza. 
The food is amazing, the location pretty and the service very good. 
We strongly recommend this place!

name: C4 Comida Tipica
description: Desayuno tipico 30Q, menu del dia 25Q (chicken soup or fried chicken), natural juices 15Q. Good cheap food, fast Wi-Fi, nice restaurant.

name: Embacadero lanchas públicas Tzanjuyu
description:
From here you can go by public boat to the towns around the lake price per person Q25 you can get there on foot or by tuk tuk.

desde aquí puedes salir en lancha publica hacia las poblaciones al rededor del lago precio por persona Q25  puedes llegar caminando o en tuk tuk.

name: Restaurante La casa del sabor
description: Good restaurant right next to the mirador Juan Dieguez Olaverri. We ask the family if we could park in their entrance and they have place for 2 campers they even close the fence during the night for safety. We are too big for the parking lot! The view is beautiful and is nice stop before explore the surrounding!

name: Museum of Paléontologia, Arqueologica de Estanzuela
description: beautiful museum, free with 2 room about Paléontologia and 2 for the archéologic one. Really interesting,  beautiful bones of a mammut and free so if you're going down to Honduras or Salvador, it's good for an 1h stop.

name: Claro Agency
description: Great place to get a SIM and cell package for all of the Americas. It works from Canada to Argentina. They are very helpful and professional.

name: Llama Huehue
description:
Nice little place in the village of Chiabal. Next to the mountains Cuchumatanes! Good place to stay if you want to go hiking. You can walk to the trail.
They have lamas, sheeps and a little farm. The family let us stay there for 15Q. They offered a bathroom as well!
10Q more if you want to visit the lamas.

name: River Crossing
description:
Beautiful road leading up to this point then turns into dirt road going to a river crossing. It was shallow and no issue for our Ford Transit. Regular cars passed as well. Not sure if an RV would be able to make it though since going in and out the river bed is pretty steep and rocky...

Edit: Approach angle and exit angle are fine for vehicles of all sizes. A bus crossed in front of us and we are 22 feet long and went through fine.

name: Firefly Gardens
description: This property is an eco garden with a tiny house Airbnb , and a couple of casitas. There is room to park smaller RVs and vans and there are also spots for tents. It is very safe and secure, on a quiet country road with zero traffic at night and minimal traffic during the day.  The property is nestled in an avocado cloud forest and has a lovely garden area to relax, it is very tranquil for a moment to rest from the road.  It is possible to access the lake for swimming and relaxing, about a 20-minute walk .The amenities include a hot solar outdoor shower and outdoor compost toilet, starlink internet as well as access to an outdoor kitchen with stove and fridge. It is about a 10 minute drive to Santiago Atitlan, and 30 minutes to San Pedro de Laguna.  Chello(Cheyo) lives on the land and he is a local Mayan who knows the area well and is very friendly and helpful. To stay here, arrange by calling Cheyo Whatsapp: +502 3326 2086 *note, Cheyo speaks Spanish, Mayan and some English. Jonathan is also staying here longer term in a full size skoolie and he speaks English and knows the area quite well too. You can also contact him for reserving a space on Whatsapp: +502 4917 3946.

name: Taller de Mecanica Clinica automotriz Morales
description: A great garage where they do all kind of mechanic work. Electronic and regular mechanics. We stopped to have our brakes checked and Tomas was very nice, serious and helped us right away. He went to France twice so he is used to foreigners. We recommend this place !

name: Hostal El Nawal
description:
Because most of the other hostels in the area have bad reviews I figured I'd enter this one. 

Basic dorm beds 50 qz/night, super friendly host and staff,  cold showers, no WiFi or Tigo mobile signal.  Large parking area that isn't gated, but is removed from the road and in sight of the cabins and restaraunt,  unlike some of the other options in the area. Felt safe parking my bike.  Far enough away from Semuc Champey to be chill, but still close enough to walk, although it is a bit of a hike up and down hill . From this spot you can flag down a truck for 10 qz if you want.  Didn't try the restaraunt on site, normal slightly touristic prices (beer 20 qz, burrito 35, pizza 70). I'm not sure if you can camp in your van here,  as I don't have one I didn't ask,  but it seems suitable. you'll still be advised by the host to have 4x4 to get here,  although the road to get to this spot is generally better than the final stretch into semuc.

name: Guayaha Hotel
description:
Large open guarded parking lot.
Leveled and suitable for large rigs.
Nice clean toilet and nice restaurant. Beautiful clean swimming pool. 
200 c per night for the parking.
A really good new paved road till San Agustín Lanquín.
We took a pickup truck to Semuc Champey, steep and unpaved road, cost us 50 c per person for both ways - worth every penny.

name: Farm Santa Eliza
description:
We are the owners of this place. The camping ground is part of an established cacoa farm. 
Phone Number: +502 3100 40 97 or +491604743766 (Whatsapp)

We speak Spanisch, Q'echi, Englisch and German. (All fluent - but different people...)
If you are interested in staying at a place with no tourist. (Exept you in the future) and you want to learn a lot about Cocoa and other plants, you are at the right place. 
Coming from Rio Dulce to Lanquin or vice versa, this i a very nice place to stay. 
For whatever reason, the first visitors came from Germany. (Dino Adventure - See the picture below)
Alhan from Guatemala and Andreas from Germany have started a joint projekt to grow Cacoa and other plants. At the moment we have 8 Hectar under management and we are aiming to go for more. The Farm is build on an agroforest approach. We are very well integrated into the community and at the moment we support a dental project in this area as well. 

Santa Maria de Cahabon is a small pueblo nearby. You will find a local market, very friendly people and a very typical environment. 

We also offer trips to the farms we work with or into the natural park just beginning 2 Miles from our place.

The Place website is the german website for dokeshi. But give us a whatsapp call and you will find out more.

By the way, place is free of charge. Would be happy if you donate to our charity project.

name: Frenos
description: good mechanic. He repaired our breaks and suspension.

name: Hotel y Restaurante Rancho Alegre
description:
Large open parking lot, clean toilet and  electricity.
Eat at the restaurant and park for the night for free.

name: Amazing informal campsite with insane view and fireplace
description:
we showed up here at 2pm, had the place for us, absolutely mindblowing view on El Fuego eruptions. 

$4pp as someone will come pick up money around 6/7pm.

dont worry about being able to do this hike alone, this is just marketing from tour companies. 

INSANE STUFF, most impressive thing I ever witnessed after years of traveling.

name: modern Mayan ceremony site
description: In use daily by locals. Lots of statues and burning of offerings. parking at the front. It's on a steep road but nothing out of the ordinary for Guatemala. free. there's a guy who cleans up and takes tips from locals

name: wifi at mcdonalds
description: free WiFi at McDonald's no password needed open till 10pm. Always busy.

name: Liss Ropa y Calzado (amazing shop)
description: Best shop in town — high quality, locally hand made garnments for men and women, unique jewelry, and some children stuff too. Shoes are amazing. I gave them all my money and wish I had more with me !!

name: Yogulato
description:
Amazing sorbets and ice cream here. Perfect place if you are feeling too hot or need to be refreshed.
You can choose between cone or cup with two toppings. The freshness of the flavors are incredible! We loved maracuya, taro and matcha.

name: Hotel Playa Linda
description: Nice, family-owned waterfront hotel. Hotel is currently undergoing several renovations inside and outside. Features include a private pool, in-room fireplace, pet friendly, secure parking, private garden with beautiful flowers from the region. I got a room with a king-bed and twin (view of Lake Atitlan) for $250Qz for 5 nights. It has surpassed all of my expectations.

name: Hotel Margot
description:
2 people, one double bed. 150 Guatemale dollars
Super secure parking. Parking entrance is on the side street

name: Hotel el Meson
description: Good clean room with 2 single beds and motorcycle parking. They have room for 2 minivans max. Paid 150 Guatemala dollars. Shared clean bathroom. One block away from Internet cafe to print papers. 2 blocks from bank. Had nice Mexican style hotdog from street vendor for 12$

name: McDonald's
description: Free WiFi at McDonald's. accessible from the parking lot close to the building

name: café hôtel posada del rio
description: Nice little café with WiFi. good choice for refreshing beverage. enought place to park under the brige for long or tall camper

name: guarded parking
description:
parking lot 20 quetzales by car. 
closed at 10 pm when there is nobody. or 2am when people are here. ok to stay overnight when it's closed
little spot in front of multiple bars and restaurant. musique could be very loud late in night when it's week-end or day off (like semana santa when we are
there some shade, little beach (not really clean) and a recreation water parc open between 9am and 5pm.
for us music start again at 7am the next morning, so for us it's too noise for what we like.
good spot if you wanna eat, dance and have fun with local.
WiFi  restrooms in restaurants

name: parking front of river
description:
we slept one night here during semana santa. planty of locals at this time but i'm pretty sure there is nobody when it's not vacation time. we paid 10quetzales to an old man (little bit deaf) for parking and ask to stay overnight. he was ok but the next morning he woke up us at 7 am to leave or paid for new day (thanks again to semana santa). we asked also locals living here to know if it's safe place, they answered us nothing appened here. 
we paid 5quetzales more by people to go to the river but when it's so warm outside YOU WANT TO GO TO REFRESH YOURSELF!
nice surprise, hen and chicks found safe place under our truck... there were sooo cute!

name: Hotel Gran Shalom 2
description: Hotel with a large event area and futbol field for rent. We parked in the secure parking lot and was offered use of the bathroom which was clean enough. Free wifi also. Paid 50q per night. Definitely the best thing we found in town after looking for a couple of hours. The local police actually brought us here after asking them for a suggestion. Our 3.3m high truck camper made it inside the gate with no problem.

name: hotel calisso
description: very nice hotel in the very nice pueblo of amatitlan.It is structured like a motel with parking, comfortable bed and great and roomy showers.The price is 125 Q if you arrive after 5 and stay until the morning after or 150 Q for 24 hours.close to the mercado and tasty comedores and located in the city center.

name: Aruma Eco Hostel
description: They allow you to stay in the camper on the parking lot (next to the road). They asked for 30 Q in total (2 people in a truck camper). You'll have access to the toilets and showers. Not secured, but felt safe although the place was a bit noisy due to the road.

name: Hotel Pasada Del Viajero
description:
Decent budget hotel to spend the night. Prices vary from 50Q to 125Q (Single occupancy), see pics for prices. All rooms include fan, "aire" rooms have ac. 

Large secure parking (see pics) with 6 official car spots, but you can fit more. Height restriction of about 10ft.

Tiendas, bakery, restaurants nearby

name: Next to Elektra Supermarket
description: Cheapest parking we found here for the bustling Sunday market. 10 Quetzales per hour. Guarded No height restriction and you don't have to hand in the keys. Big rig friendly.

name: Villas Hotel Jabel Tinamit
description: A bit more expensive but very nice place if you are in need of a few days rest. Secured parking, garden, terrace and patio. Decent wifi. Very nice room. Very attentive staff and great breakfast included. Located minutes from resto and street food and about 1 km from the lake and public ferry dock. We paid 380q per night.

name: Don Fredy
description: I don't normally add Restaurants but this one deserves to be mentioned. Only 2 different options on the menu (go with the Loma). Only locals the two times we were there. Seating outside in plastic chairs/tables across the road from the lake. There is an option for a small portion for 40Q which satisfied hungry cyclists with the delicious tortillas, papas, y ensaladas. Cervezas @ 8Q - Hard to beat for the lovely but expensive touristy island.

name: Hotel Embajador
description:
The family is very kind, its a fair prize and depending on your choice of room and hotel you may have a lovely view of the surroundings and a good rest!
They may allow you to use the kitchen too.

name: El Buen Pastor
description: This restaurant is close to Hotel Hollywood, which is a great staging location for an early morning crossing into El Salvador. The couple is Erick and Elvirena. They serve delicious pupusas (queso, frijol, chicharrones when we were there) and tacos (res when we were there). Pupusas are Q5 each. Erick kindly walked to the store to get the drinks we asked for. Really nice people and a pleasure to support.

name: Mahanaim Hotel International
description: Great place to stay, especially if you’re riding a motorcycle. 200 Quetzales/night with A/C, cheaper without. Lots of hotels in town, but this one had secure motorcycle parking in back. Walking distance to everything, street money exchangers around the corner. Swimming pool, real nice coffee shop, wifi.

name: Copias
description:
Good place to make copies. 
.....
Un lugar bueno para hacer copias.

name: Cafe Boheme
description: Probably the best french bakery, smoothie place in central America. beautiful and unexpected place in Antigua.

name: minas de sal
description: interesting place were locals gather salt water for cooking on Mondays and Tuesdays around noon. Not a traditional mine but still super interesting

name: Techron gas station
description: Gas station where they were happy to let me overnight when the dark caught up with me. Quiet and very dark at night (power was down after a tree brought down cables nearby) between 9pm and 5am, when the generator was turned back on. Clean toilets and a lovely cold shower, which overnighting truckers were making heavy use of in the evening. Electrical sockets available.

name: InterSport Gas Station
description: All other spots at the Tajumulco Trailhead we're closed when we arrived late. asked at the Gas Station. Owner was very friendly, said the station is open 24h and we can use the open banos. Quied and safe. The whole area seems to be calm and unspectacular.

name: Clinicas Medicas
description: Here is a place with many different specialists- Doctors, dentists etc. Our little one had a very bad stomach bug and we sought advice from pediatrician Dr Vanesa Lemus González. She was very thorough - carrying out a complete health check in addition to the investigation we needed, and we were very pleased. She took samples, had us nip over to the lab to get it examined and an hour later, we were able to consult with her again and receive the right medicine for our daughter’s bacteria. This consultation cost 200 Quetzales. We would highly recommend. Please note- appointment bookings are required in advance.

name: Miratengo II
description:
Route to the Miratengo campground: at the end of the street was a gate. we asked, If we could stay here for the night. they charged us 50 quetzal. grassy leveled parking lot with Clean toilets and a warm (Electronic heater) shower. Direct Access to Acatenango Trail.
Edit: there is a clear sign to Miratengo on the left hand side if you’re coming from Antigua. Take the dirt road all the way up to the dead end with a gate. Honk your horn and someone will open the door. If not, wait, there is a family living there and they will be back.

name: Lavanderia Lili
description: 6 Q for libre. Good service and ready in the day

name: Calma Cafe
description:
Spacious outdoor cafe in a gated area that includes parking during hours of operation. Food is good, prices reasonable and it has good wifi. I asked the owner if it was possible to park for the night and he suggested that we parked across the street, but he offered to leave some lights on in our direction to increase security.
Recommended for a stop in Huehuetenango!

name: Cuevas Chicoy
description:
Caves a couple of kms of the main road. A Mayan sacred site. 
Very cool. The path is a  bit sketchy but ok. 10Q per person entrance fee.

name: Hospedaje Maya
description:
Incredible local family! Most warmhearted people I met on this trip; simply amazing to meet them. They have a room for travelers, serve food and don't tell you a price. So you decide how much to give. Can't say how much I recommend this place!
Jonas also guides you up the volcano, for a third of the price you pay in an agency. They have an organization of local guides, where guides are not exploited as they are with the agencies.

name: Finca Sacmoc
description:
An eco retreat in the jungle north of Coban.
Accommodation,  walks, swimming holes, waterfalls, tubing, a swimming pool. 
A fairly rough road to get here. The owner suggested 2hrs from Coban 35kms away. It took us 1hr on light motorcycles. Possible in cars ,trucks and campers with good clearance and patience .Worth the effort.

name: Casa Madera
description: Great local restaurant selling good simple food at a great price. We had lunch here and came back for dinner.

name: Parqueo Público
description:
The other place is not accepting people sleeping inside the van. So we stayed for the night in this one. It’s safe with a fence. It’s 100 quetzales the night. It has restrooms.
El otro lugar que está registrado ya no acepta personas durmiendo en vans. Entonces nos quedamos a dormir en este parqueo, seguro con portón, cobran 100quetzales la noche. Hay servicio sanitario.

name: Hospedaje Xesuj Tsununa
description:
This is a small hospedaje 200-300 meters away from the Lago Atitlan. Right before Centro de Salud y Nutrizion Tsununa. There are 3 rooms, but we asked for camping as there is grassy area which can take up to 3-4 small tents(check photos). There is a number to contact the owner right at the entrance as he lives near the center of the village(see photo).

He gave us a price of 30 quetzales for three people per night(2 adults and 1 kid). There's a toilet and cold shower both in good condition. 

That's the cheapest we have found so far after being on the lake for almost 10 days. 

This place is more for backpackers. Also a small car/van can enter here though. 

The patio is clean and looks nice. As the owners rents the rooms for around 1200 quetzales per month they are occupied most of the time by travellers. There's a kitchen, but we haven't looked very much at it, though it seems dirty due to careless by people who rent the place. One of the guy renting here has a dog running around.

Overall OK place to spend several days exploring the area. 

The entrance gate does not have a locker. The owner said it is very quiet here, but we locked it around 10:00 pm with our own locker for more safety. During day there's a lot of tuk-tuks passing by as the road which is 100 m away from the hospedaje is the road which goes to the dock with the boats. After 9 pm it gets really calm and quiet. 

Some of the neighbors do not speak Spanish, only Kaq'chikel so if there is no one around you can ask them to contact owner if you do not own guatemalan number. This was our case. 

Happy travels.

name: Sabados y Domingo venta de comida
description:
We arrived in the village and look where to camp before doing the hiking alone, without guide. 

It was important one day acclimatization as we were going to hike with our 4 years old. 

We asked here to camp in the backyard of the store, which is on the left side on the road coming from direction Chimaltenango.

To put our tent they asked 50 quetzales we negotioted for 30 quetzales for all of us. Two adults/one child.

There is a clean toilet and shower. We didn't ask for the shower as we said during negotiation that we wouldn't use the hot shower as it was very cold. Maybe with hot shower price could go up.

They also serve food during weekends and during the night some people came over to eat. Also they rent two rooms, I think in quite good condition. From outside looked clean. Where people eat there is a stove though we didn't ask to use it. 

Overall calm place to spend one night before trekking. 

The entrance point for the hiking is really close to the place, maybe 3-4 minutes walking. 

You could also camp on top of the house/store which has a flat roof and the view is amazing. We didn't do there as it was raining. 

The brother of one of the guys who runs the place is renting equipment. We need backpack, but didn't rent as he asked for 75 quetzales per day. Across the street a place with banner "Guia Local Don Valeriano" also rents equipment. We rent backpack 70 litres in terrific condition for 50 quetzales for 2-3 days. The son of Don Valeriano is called David and he is also a guide. 

Happy travels.

name: Route to Flores
description:
If you are going from Semuc to Flores this route is not the best. This route is for 4x4 vehicles and there are warnings of people asking for money on the road. It’s better to go back to Coban and then turn to Flores, even when the route is supposed to be longer, because this street is completely paved.
---
Si va de Semuc Champey hacia Flores es mejor no tomar esta ruta porque la carretera es de piedra por muchos kms, es para vehículos 4x4 y también hay avisos de personas pidiendo peajes más adelante. Es mejor devolverse a Coban y de ahí desviarse hacia Flores, ya que esa calle sí está pavimentada aunque la ruta diga que es más larga.

name: Playa dorada
description: Parking by the lake without amenities 50 qtz to sleep pleasant asphalt road. Too bad the parking lot is average but the view is pleasant. Does not justify the detour

name: Villa Margarita
description: Private w/ AC & bathroom 247q. Couldn’t find anything cheaper with AC (41’C today!) in our walk around. Wider street with parking, we were able to park right below our balcony, so we can keep an eye on it sort of.

name: Parking Jirech
description: Left our truck here for 3 nights, was safe on our return! We also left a bag outside the truck and Antonio kept it safe for us until we came back. 50/night (started at 80/night).

name: Katok- sausages, jams, cheeses
description: Awesome selection of takeaway uncooked sausages, had about 10 kinds. Not too expensive. Also ribs, hams, cheeses, goat cheese, jams. The restaurant was great too!

name: Refills - Somos Tierra
description: Bring your own containers to refill anything from flour to nuts, shampoos, hand sanitizer, eco cleaners, snacks, oils, vinegar. It’s great! Also sells natural soaps and bath stuff.

name: Custom cushions, upholstery, sewing
description: Tapiceria Miguel custom-made new cushions for our camper and did an awesome job! He has lots of fabrics to choose from, plus we bought some funky pattern at the market and he incorporated it! We gave him custom dimensions and he nailed it! Definitely recommend! It’s the blue building, don’t think there’s a sign. Check the photo for his whatsapp.

name: Space with grass to walk dogs
description: We found it really hard to let our dogs go to the bathroom in downtown Antigua because all of the green areas are fenced off. We found this great little stretch of dirt road with lots of grass and area for them to use the bathroom. Bring your own poop bags and keep it clean.

name: Vivero y Café de La Escalonia
description: Gorgeous garden setting with plants and water features, great coffee and great breakfast. Pet friendly on a leash. Huge selection of natural goodies in shop as well. Coffee q15, omelet q31, med smoothie q25.

name: Large parking area
description: There are 2 large parkings side by side. Allowed to camp in the rig for the night. Belongs to hotel next door that has security 24h. 50Q per night.

name: Next to potato fields
description:
I talked to several locals and they had no problem that I stay here. At night gets cold. People is super nice, all said hi and some stopped to talk with me, in the afternoon one of the neighbors came to tell me where he lives in case I need something and wish good night. You can rent bathroom for 2Q at lamas place in the village.
Also I recommend the ecological trail Piedra Cuache, from here go straight to the mountain.

name: Hostal del Angel
description:
As of the time of writing, it's a new hostal that isn't formerly opened yet. However, the owner (who also owns a restaurant right next door) let us park on the grounds for the night. 50q per person.

Beautiful spot with incredible views across the whole valley. Wonderful mountain air. We were given a key to use the bathrooms in one of the hostel rooms - though this may not happen for you if all the hostel rooms are full once it opens properly.

There are some sheep and some ducks and some rabbits and the staff are super friendly. They even proactively helped us level our vehicle.

Good WiFi. Electricity (if you have a very long cord). No Blackwater dumping. Good cell signal.

Up to full size Sprinter van would fit no problem. Big rigs may fit if you're a solid driver and are ok with backing out all the way - it's a bit narrow. Worth checking.

name: Public Parking Area on Lake Shore
description:
We followed the other parking indication close by to get here but discovered if we came another hundred meters towards the shore there was a grassy area outside of the chocked and parking lines of the official parking area. We spent two nights here and no one bothered us at all. Lots of locals pass by on foot and there’s lots of cars that arrive during the day but at night it was super quiet and felt very safe. 

Tons of free roaming dogs around but they got along just fine with our dogs. Incredible views of the lake! Walking distance to lots of little touristy shops and restaurants. Cross over the little foot bridge to the east and there are some really neat little beaches only a few minutes walk away.

name: church parking lot
description: basic gravel parking lot just next to the road. a bit noisy in the morning because of trucks climbing the road. but very fine for one night in the middle of nowhere. locals said it is very safe. nobody came, only few women crossing the way to the next village. enjoy!

name: Public Dock - narrow dead end street
description: If your rig is small enough like a minivan or small van you can make it to a parking spot right in front of a little grassy area right on the lake. It’s a little tricky to turn around as there is very limited space but if you can make it I highly recommend it! Absolutely gorgeous views. Felt really safe and quiet

name: CERNE women association
description: CERNE is a local association that works with women which suffer violence at home. They offer psycological and financial support as well as they teach them a job. They also coordinate with local police to protect them. The women work here to support themselves and produce very nice traditional clothes, which you can buy for a fair price. The shirts in the first picture are around 200-300 quetzales.

name: Taller de Rolando
description:
Rolando was recommended by a local from Huehuetenango who has a VW Beatle. He s a multi brand mechanic. I saw lot of cars there, mostly 4x4. He also has a lot of experience in VW classics as he had more that 20.

At the beginning he thought my kombi had a problem with a piston buton  making a deeper inspection detected the issue was in the clutch flywheel, simpler and cheaper.
In one day we lowered the engine, sent it to a turner and in the next day I was en route again. Honest, competent and fare prices.

He also allows you to sleep in the mechanic shop, he likes meeting travelers and has one of the best views that any other mechanic shop.
Phone: +502 3231 0848

name: Front of Pelicanos Hotel
description: The beach in front of the Pelicanos Hotel, near the wooden swing. The security guard may allow you to use the outdoor shower, as well as the bathroom and hammocks (this is not guaranteed). This is a public section of beach, so it is perfectly legal to camp here. We stayed here for a week and we had no issues with permissions or security. While we were there, we positioned logs that make a nice area to sit around a campfire. Bring mosquito repellent.

name: In front Hotel La casa del Lacandon
description:
We parked in the evening but we didn't stay in the van until night. 
We came to sleep at 8pm and nobody bored us.  Slept ok.

name: Palacio Municipal Morales Izabal
description:
We stop here for overnight, asked a policeman and he said was ok. 
There are some local  sellers, grocery, fastfood. 
During the day the transit starts early morning, but at night is quiet and safe.

name: public playa (signed)
description: This is a public area, with a small pull off on the side of the road for parking (2 or 3 cars would fit). trees for hammocks, bbq pits and a couple benches. i dont see any reason as to why you couldnt wild camp here but we just hung around for the afternoon. it is opposite posada del cerro

name: check point
description:
They asked us for our vehicle papers and passport, and they asked us questions. we saw that other cars were searched personally.
---
Nos pidieron los papeles del vehículo y el pasaporte, y nos hicieron preguntas. vimos que a otros autos les hicieron cateo personal.

name: Free parking
description:
It is a very wide spot with a few trees and palm trees, we met Neri, a man who lives at the end of the street and he told us that the land belongs to his friend and that there is no problem parking and spending the night here. Even Neri offered us to shower at her place.
About 50 meters away there is a street with a white fence that leads to the beach, but we are not recommended to stay parked between the street because cars pass by. He told us that it is very quiet and that in Monterico and Hawaii everything is more expensive and the parking lots charge, and also the beaches are more private with houses facing the sea.
---
